comment:
@shwwnn The presupposition of your opening statement is faulty. We "deserve" nothing.

The humanity, or lack there of, in the price of labor is consequential. My argument is not counter to that idea. My argument is that it is not the role of government to set that value. To do so would require a devaluation of the top for the benefit of the bottom. This can seem benevolent but, it is immoral.


Unions were formed by the wage-earners in order that they set their own valuation of their labor. This is the best way forward. At least in my opinion.


Globalism makes unionizing more difficult and possibly impossible. Why pay $20 per hour here in the States when that same labor can be purchased for $2.00 overseas?


The answer to this quandary is yet unknown. But, if all the ditch diggers refused to dig for anything less than a livable wage, then they would either need to find a new job, or they would get a livable wage.

This is the point of the movie. Not that capitalism is bad, but that the ditch diggers do not cooperate for the greater good of them as a class.


I lost a business in the early 2000's because cheap immigrant labor came in and said they would do the job for less than I could comfortably live on. I was not willing to become working class poor. If none of the native labor would have accepted the new lower wage, then none of us would need to look for other work.


Getting people to work for the greater good is difficult. It is far easier to have the government force it by laws and regulations. But I will likely never support a government picking winners and losers.

comment:
Too much anti-capitalism in the analysis. Yea, it's all kinda correct, but it's not the capitalism that is screwing people. It's PEOPLE that are screwing people, and that's just because that's what people do.

And don't forget that communist and socialist countries have inequality too, and in terms of communist countries, the inequality is actually way larger than in capitalist countries. Communist countries just take the capitalist approach of companies-rule-all and merge all the comanies into a single company, then merge that one company with a government and voila, you just made a communism out of capitalism. Communism is is literally the extreme version of capitalism, with a single government-company body ruling all.

The trick is to keep the ruling class fragmented and divided. They will still be powerful, but as long as they're fighting each other just the right amount, it can find its chaotic balance of least-evil.


Ofcourse it would be much better if it was not necessary to have it this way, and all people were just good to each other. But it would also be better if cancer didn't exist, mosquito bites tickled and if people could regrow lost limbs. Neither of those are reality.

comment:
I don‚Äôt think they are in the same exact social class. With this movie‚Äôs use of vertical camera work, we see that the poor family lives in a basement apartment, but there is a window still shining light through. Personally, I think the light symbolizes privilege and hope. However, the former maid and her husband are completely underground, with no light at all. I feel that the mother does not chose to acknowledge that she is poor like the couple because in this socioeconomic hierarchy, she has more privilege then the couple in the basement. There are people that are below the social class of the poor family, which shows that it is not just rich, middle-class, and poor. There are different subgroups of all of them that are more privileged than others.

This film did not just portray the conflicts between the rich and poor. It also showed how the different subgroups of the poor fight each other to have a chance to move up this social hierarchy.

Rich and Poor are both a state of mind. At the end of the day it's up to you to make your situation great. Wanting to have people help you and wanting to have people do the work for you are two different things and isn't very far from slavery.

So the question you should ask yourself is what am I doing to make my situation better for myself and people like me?

You could build your own house, you could teach yourself stress relievers, you can put whats truly important in life into perspective, you could take care of your family and teach them how to take care of themselves and eachother, you can grow your own food and cook them and feed yourself and others around you, you can realize you have all the tools you need in front of you instead of relying on a government or currency or slavery or false ideologies to guide you towards a rich or poor life.

comment:
The Australian Government receives revenues of around 520 billion a year and the whole of all companies in Australia earnt around 233billion after tax. (That figure would include small businesses that pay themselves out of the profit in their company.)

We aren't a capitalistic society, if we were we would have the right to grow food in our backyards and sell it or teach our children instead of the state paying 20,000 on average per child per year. We are a crony capitalist society, we pander to Government. Whoever gets Government work whether that be a job or a Government Contract or even a field of work that was created out of regulation by Government has the ability to accumulate assets and become wealthy. The majority of people in private enterprise with exception to directors in a top 200 company earn less then Government workers. And when the Government deregulates things like milk or taxis it causes the job to be virtually profitless.

Even in those top asx 200 companies a lot of the earnings would be from government permits to mine or engineering contracts for a highway or research grants for medication or income from medicare.


The Government may not control the means of production (which is what communism is) but it does control where virtually all the money in the economy is used

comment:
Just subscribed! Not only were you informative but you asked a good question of "Who are the parasites?"

The kind of NeoLiberal Capitalism that has arisen in society is a lot more pervasive than we are willing to admit. Even I have this mentality of "I have worked for this, why should anyone else benefit from it" that convinces me to believe in less taxation, deregulation and free trade. Imagine going from even low class and working your way to middle class only to realize that the government will tax you more now because of your income bracket. The thought of actually working more, working harder, only to then earn a smaller percentage of what you expected to make is quite disheartening and my knee-jerk response is to say "government, please stay away from it."

But then I realize it's definitely the mentality of the rich as well. I am talking about those who earn disparate amounts of annual income who have convinced themselves they work hard enough and have managed the company enough that they deserve not to be taxed as much. And so, they either send their money off to tax havens, find loopholes in tax law (why U.S. tax law is so damn complicated), or some other way to get out of paying what is required by law. And guess what - when they even manage to fail like they did back in 2007-08, they have convinced the rest of society, the government that they need these bail outs because they are too big to fail. It's okay when they ask for financial support but for anybody else within society, good luck.

The reality that Parasite conveys at the end of the day is that everyone has blood on their hands. Every single consumer in a first world country to those even rising to the top. The only reason why people do not see it that way is because we have a monetary system that keeps things "civil" when in reality we have traded one bad thing for something worse - exploitation, low-paying wages, treating humans like machines, lying to employees by convincing them to work through bad circumstances, etc. Want to see an example of this? Watch Netflix's American Factory and see how NeoLiberal Capitalism accomplishes this... (I'm sure the rich cannot wait for machines to be their full-time employees. But, in the meantime, they will settle for full-time employees who are willing to accept themselves as mere machines).

This video terrifies me by his ideas based on Marxism and the idea that the poor family are not the villains on this movie, but "evil capitalism".
Living on a country of the third world I can surely say that I can see a very realistic reflection on how poor people think and act.
How they think the rich steal from the poor (which is false) the rich are providing the poor with PAY jobs, and the poor are benefiting themselves from those jobs.
In fact the flown scene, it affects the poor family the most, because they where at that moment, being parasites on the rich family instead of tacking care of their own... if they where on their basement, they could have been able to save more of their pertinences, not to blame the rich family, they have achieved a lot by themselves, not stealing from the poor.
The idea that all rich steal from the poor is obnoxious idea, the rich provide with jobs to a lot of people, the rich class is the most job provider in the world.
I was poor in my childhood and I worked, I cannot have a house like the rich family in parasite, but I did my homework, I worked my ass off and Im no longer poor, Im middle class, but I can see how the poor people looks at middle and high class, how they think we are stealing from them, we are not.
We just worked harder, we where more disciplined, we didn't went for the easiest road (like the poor family in this movie does a lot), we earn all that we have.

comment:
The parasite(s) in the film are the members of the poor family. In the very beginning they are shown stealing wifi. When a password is put in place they make multiple guesses at it in order keep using something that they aren‚Äôt paying for.
When they turn in the pizza boxes for payment. They try to swindle money out of the two young kids running the business regardless of the shoddy work they did folding them.

When the son gets hired by the rich family they then put together various schemes to steal the jobs of the other employees. Going so far as to kill them in order to maintain their hold on the Parks.

The Park family is shown as model citizens. The dad works hard every day. He‚Äôs home every evening with his family. Taking them on weekend getaways. Making sure his son has a wonderful birthday. Taking care of his wife. He even remarks about the horrid behavior of the driver to have sex in his car. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt we pay him well?‚Äù They‚Äôre trying to do the right thing. While the Kim family is sneaking around and stealing whiskey and food. The Kims want to put in the minimum investment while getting the largest return. Everyone in the Kim family are good at what they do (driving, teaching, and house managing). But they would rather destroy everything than just do what is right.

What frightens me is everyone who watched this movie is on the side of the conniving MURDERING thieves. Rather than the people who are providing jobs for others and a good life for their kids.

Also, if you stink, then have some respect for yourself and others and wash that smell away. This is a typical thought pattern in todays modern society. Everyone else is the problem and I have no responsibilities. The wrong are right and the right are wrong.

comment:
...Video does a good job of pushing socialism and interventionism. I could debunk the misunderstandings about economics or the points where interpretations are willfully taken in a direction to push the narrative, but I'll go straight to the main point instead. The entire narrative is based on a set of premises that misses one extremely important key fact. One that makes the whole of the narrative crumble. For those that don't get it on their own, here goes:

If neoliberalism keeps rich people rich and poor people poor, and specially if the idea that poor people can become rich by effort is a constructed lie, as the narrative of the video claims, and as is reinforced in the video's description, where neoliberal capitalism is outright pointed as "the boogie man" of the film, then why the BRRT[A-10 sound] do we have examples of rich people becoming poor, and more importantly, of poor people becoming rich? Specially considering that the cases of poor people becoming rich only happen (to people who are not dictators or corrupt government officials, or affiliates to those) in capitalistic societies, and further, specially noting the direct correlation to economic freedom (ie, among other things, less bureaucracy and intervention)?

Why are the non-neoliberal, non-capitalistic societies that end up in economic, and thus eventually societal, disaster and ruin? While economic freedom and less government intervention is directly correlated to economic success and reduction of the poor?

ü§î ü§î ü§î ü§î ü§î

If you are in favor of (more?) interventionism of any kind, I'll ask you (any reader) to put your biases and (mis-?)conceptions about capitalism aside for a second, and think about this next point, and think about it seriously: Maybe, just maybe, it's ****not**** that the pro-captalism argument is based on ideas that the poor are parasites of the rich (as outright stated in the video at 12:51), but rather, based on the realization and understanding that:

EVERYONE is affected by taxation. SPECIALLY the poorer, at any given wealth level, since the richer (at that wealth level or the ones above it) can offset the cost of taxation by pushing it down the suply/demand line through raising the prices of their products, or avoid it entirely by moving their assets away somewhere with less taxation. The later case being specially bad for the poor, since now they not only have to deal with the cost of taxation, but they have to do so with less choice about their work and their pay (since some or all of the rich moved their assets, ie factories, ie jobs away). --- Basically, "the rich" is everyone, because everyone is rich to different extents; and "the rich" aren't retarded, and if you try to take money away from people, no matter what level of rich they are, they will do their best to preserve it.

If you are in favor of intervention in the economy or socialistic measures to "help the poor", you are in favor of hurting people and businesses through taxation or bureaucracy. And if you are in favor of hurting people and businesses, you are ultimately AGAINST the poor. Because:

---That very rich guy? Is not going to be taxed, or deal with bureaucracy on his businesses, more than he is willing to be; if you over-tax him or his company, he will move himself and/or his company away, along with all the related assets, because he can, and he doesn't have to deal with the BS you created.
---That not-so-rich guy? Same as the rich guy, except with more limited options. If you over-tax him or over-burden him, he might not be able to move away; but that small business that he planned to build with the money he managed to save from the past 5 years? Yea, he gave up on that for now, and the money is stuck in the bank earning him dividends to offset the higher taxes you directly or indirectly created.
---That kinda-poor guy? Same as the not-so-rich guy, except with even less options. He was working part-time, and spending the spare time getting himself a better education than he currently has in order to move up in life, but he got fired when the factory he worked at closed down to move to another state or country; turns out he was employed by the very rich guy who is moving his stuff away. So now he has to work full-time with over-time just to pay the bills, since, you know, there are less jobs and taxes are higher.
---That actually poor guy? He is either dying of hunger on the streets, or having to rely on charity (forced by government as, haha the irony, more taxes; or, preferably, voluntary), instead of being independent, thanks to ****not**** getting a job created, maintained, or freed by any of the guys above. All thanks to your intervention that was, ironically, intended to help him.

The reasons communism fails is not exclusive to communism. Economy, when left free, is self-regulating through supply and demand, and most problems people point to as being the fault of liberalism actually stem from interventionism. Lastly, unforeseen consequences are the bane of any interventionist idea or ideals. Socialists and interventionists aren't evil. I get where you come from. I was one of you not too long ago. But you have to realize that the economy goes a LOT deeper than your top-level, superficial analysis (and if you think your analysis is not superficial, you're wrong; because even the very best economist only has a superficial understanding of economics; there are so many factors that noone can claim they fully understand economics; and those who do are lying; that's how deep it goes). There are consequences to consequences to consequences (...). And your objective might be a utopia, but the paths that point toward those utopias, without exception, actually lead to either distopias or economic ruin.

If you want to learn at least the least-wrong path, it's to let the market self-regulate instead of trying to regulate it. And if you want to understand why, well, no one has the ultimate answer (those that claim they do, again, are lying), but Mises and the libertarians seem to have figured out a lot of this stuff. They don't know any magic answers to poverty, but at least they figured out what doesn't work and why, and statistics on economic freedom worldwide prove they are right or at least the least wrong.

Lastly, remember: The true enemy is not wealth inequity; it's lack of wealth. It really doesn't matter if the richest 1% can afford a f*****g interplanetary space-ship, if the poorest can afford a house and a car. It's when the rich go away, together with the jobs they create, and the poor are struggling to feed, that we get the real problems. --- Wealth distribution often presents itself as an exponential curve on a truly free market. The poor are many, and the rich are few and REALLY rich. And so people often think that that must be the root for the problem of poverty, when actually, it's not. The problem is how low is the bottom at the start of the distribution. And counter-intuitively, often, the easier it is for the rich, and more of "the rich" there are, the higher that bottom also is, and the less poor are "the poor".

comment:
from Asia here.......move to Australia that's what I always say, Australia is as close to paradise as u get on earth.

Parasite is a depiction of extreme poverty classes and massive wealth gap divides u often find in many successful developed Asian countries,south Korea,Hong Kong,Singapore......in this places u sometimes find wages can be as low as $700 a month despite a world class GDP per capital that's easily among the top twenty countries in the world.

Australia on the other hand is different,it is a every man's country,not just a country for crazy rich folks...u will never find a class of genuinely poor folks whom are already working 50 hour weeks and still earning less than $1200 a month.......a factory worker/packer in Aussie makes $21 an HR,a convinence store worker makes $26 an HR....assuming u are willing to work in ausland,u will never be uncomfortable.
Theres only 2 percent millionaires in Australia,but the people are not poor either....how can u when working at McDonald's net u $700 a week,with overtime easily pushing $1000 a month.

On the other hand,say my country,Singapore.....nearly 10 percent of our population are millionaires in networth.....easily one in four or five own a property over a million dollars.

And on the other side u have the masses and hordes of slaves,the bottom 10 percent earning less than $800 a month,bottom 20 percent clearing less than 1.4k a month and bottom 35 to 40 percent making less than 2.3k a month....

comment:
Edit: Okay I admit I did not see the news actually saying Mr. Park was killed proper. Completely my bad.

I'd like to pose an argument that further cements the disparity between the Parks and the Kims

Mr. Park didn't die.

To explain: If you look at the scene in particular in which Ki-Jung and Mr. Park were stabbed, you can see that they were both blatantly stabbed in exactly the same place, the intermediate spot between the shoulder and the chest. Now as you all might know, not much really important exists in that particular spot, maybe a bone or large artery/vein. Getting stabbed in that spot might be incredibly painful, but in these days of our advanced healthcare technology, you most certainly wouldn't die.

However, what happens to them both after the fact is very telling of this disparity. You see Kim Ki-Jung effectively covered in blood, losing it really profusely. Her fate determined at that very moment. Mr. Park, on the other hand, has a nice clean stab, something that could easily be fixed by the best medical care he can afford. Now I understand that it was never explicitly stated that Mr. Park didn't die or not, but judging by the fact that one was losing blood so quickly and the other might as well have been clean as a whistle, I think that it's easy to say that Mr. Park's money and status protected him from death.

Considering the overall theme of how the Parks separate themselves from the impoverished to a disgusting degree, I think this argument is rather sound.

comment: it's definitely not either one thing or the other. yes, in my country we already had general colorist sentiments but then we were colonized by white people, and it became even more deep-rooted because of oppression that white people are superior. then we started consuming western media, where majority of the representation was white. all of these factors contributed to the rise of fairness creams and whitewashing, and our own entertainment industry propagated those same ideas of fairness by trying to imitate the west. colorism in asia is quite complex and differs from country to country so i dont think the video is misrepresenting it entirely but i think modern instances like consuming western entertainment in general also definitely does have a lot to do with colorism in asia in today's age. ofc i'm not an expert lol so feel free to correct me if you think i'm wrong, i'm just basing this on what i grew up with and how consuming western media disproportionately (+ the subsequent erasure of my own culture over time due to colonialism) shaped my life and perception. our standards of beauty were indeed eurocentric during the late 20th century onwards because that was what we mainly consumed.

comment: Hi, good video, definitely dropping a like and subscribing. However, I want to pick out one fallacy that you put forward which is probably due to your own Eurocentrism and possibly a bit of projection and lack of cultural awareness. Light skin has been a beauty standard in many cultures but particularly in East Asian cultures since ancient times. The Geisha's white make-up were not inspired through some sort of masochistic reverence for European white skin for instance. In fact, this light skin beauty paradigm is actually more relevant to your analysis than you might realise.  It is better explained through class; as people with darker skin/tans were usually the worker-class who stayed in the sun all day and did all the dirty, sweaty, hard-work so darker skin -> lower class, light skin -> upper class. This is a beauty standard deeply rooted in many cultures in Eurasia and the Middle East and has very little to do with colonialism as you purport in your addendum. In fact, if we were to go down the rabbit-hole of colonialism in the case of Korea, they were only ever subjugated by other east Asian dynasties like Imperial Japan, Mongols and various Chinese dynasties.

comment: The economic system was supposed to be just a barter system. Accumulation of wealth shouldn't have been a competition like it has become in our society. It should have been there to ensure that everyone gets what they need. There's enough for everyone's need but not enough for everyone's greed. But at this point, greed and corruption are almost as much a part of humankind as religion, fear, anger, lust and love are. There's no running from it. The government, the people, the proletariat have to constantly keep each other in check, but the first thing we must do is recognize that no class or faction or race is evil for just being different. We must all recognize and look within our own communities and classes to see and root out the evil ones that allow the other side to generalize us. These rich/poor divides, hatred for the other kind of human beings, things like this have existed ever since the first apes started walking upright and will always exist. It will take a huge amount of technological progress to bring the society to a level that almost every person is one day able to afford to have his needs fulfilled and the rich and greedy will have enough to fulfil their greeds. comment: Sorry but the statement that  "Neo-Liberal capitalism takes economic responsibility away from the government and places it in to the hands of free-market institutions and private individuals" is quite obvious nonsense. Economic responsibility never belonged to the government to begin wit. It belongs to the free-market institutions and individuals who generate the wealth. It is in fact the government that must take that responsibility away from private institutions and individuals, those who make up the economy and thus collectively share the responsibilities of managing it. It is the government that must use force to intercede in the economy. Free-market capitalism is the natural state of human economic behavior, not some cruel invention imposed upon humanity, and the period in time in which economic responsibility was denied to the people who made the wealth by the government was the period we refer to as FEUDALISM. Which is exactly what these "socialist" and "communist" societies degenerate in to. The example you yourself have used of sweat shop factories in China, "communist" China, are proof of that. Feudalism only ended when power began to become dispersed, through democratic ideals, to the wider society. The free market is the result of a free society.

comment: I love your flipped interpretation where the rich are actually also living off the hard work of the poor in a parasitic way, just as the poor family here are parasites and living off the rich family. But if you take it one step further, if two species are parasites of each other, it's actually no longer a parasitic relationship, but a symbiotic one. This means that contrary to the doom and gloom that this movie portrays, in reality the rich need the poor to work hard and the poor need the rich to give them scraps - a mutually beneficial relationship is possible, unlike what this movie leads you to believe (most people are not nearly as inhumane as what is shown in the film - rich people do give and give generously through philanthropy and poor people do show gratefulness as well). This movie is deliberately pessimistic, but there are always stars of hope in the vast sea of darkness in the night sky. Parasite intends to terrify and I agree with that - but without an optimistic interpretation, it comes off as heavily unbalanced - one of the main reasons I did not enjoy the film despite it's well-crafted cinematography.

comment:
I recently watched Parasite. At first I thought
"Yeah it's good, but... HOW DID THIS WIN THE OSCARS?"

The plot and theme was kinda simple with an added shock-factor in the end, but other than that, I've seen anime with better shizz...

I watched it with the premise that this movie was supposed to show the desparity between social classes, but I failed to see how the movie highlighted it. The rich gave them jobs, treated them and compensated them fairly, and yet the Kim Family seemed like they wanted to take everything.
They're cunning, and very underhanded, a textbook Parasite to their "host". It definitely showed why the movie was called "Parasite", but I was desperately looking for the "Rich Vs poor" desparity thingy that critiques always say. I really couldn't.
Yeah, I get that the Kim family is poor, but it didn't show enough of the "struggle" or they only showed minamal scenes of their poverty which in all honesty, looked like the border between a middle class and lower class here in the Philippines.
So I finished the movie feeling pissed at Mr. Kim for doing something so heinous over something so petty...

But then I started reading discussions about it and explanations to why such scenes were portrayed and the cinematography involved.

And then it hit me... The reason why I sympathize with the Parks more and why I was left dumbfounded by the ending...

I FORGOT TO CHECK MY PRIVILEGE...

I lack empathy towards what the Kim family goes through to even consider why they'd go to such lengths to be "parasites".
Also a lack of understanding on what "Korean Poverty" is and how their society works. Also the pride and dignity that the Kim family puts at stake and how they want to regain it.

Makes me realize that I'm probably part of the problem that was being highlighted in the Movie.

Guess that's why it won oscars and other awards. It threw a lot of bricks and hit the right people.

@Jonathan Salazar If they were real people I'd say that you're right. However, they're not and all we have is their characterization and backstory. The wife has no real life skills. She is a house wife who can't maintain a household. The husband is rich, but is so out of touch that he literally cannot stand the smell of poor people. He regularly talks about "crossing the line", yet regularly does this with his employees. They put little value into their employees and discard them at a moments notice.

Add on to the fact that true rags to riches stories are practically nonexistent. Anyone who is as wealthy as them rarely if ever come from poverty. So it is extremely reasonable to infer they didn't claw their way to the top.

comment:
@Ryleeman54number2 The young guy you are talking about didn't work his way up to work for them legitimately. While he and his "friend" are discussing the job at the beginning of the film they acknowledge the fact that he will have to fake being a college student even though his English is far better than any of the actual students that would get the job instead.
(This can be seen as showing the barrier of entry to many jobs, or things in general, being more than just hard work and skill.)

Even if that wasn't the case this guy needed to have a connection through this guy to get the job anyway, which a lot of people trying to break in often don't have. (There are suggestions in the film that the family have only relatively recently become poor which would explain how he has this guy as a connection)

Also just as a side note the "friend's" reasoning for choosing him for the job shows how he thinks of himself as better than the young guy. He doesn't deny the young guy calling himself a loser and in fact leans into it by saying he chose him because he didn't want to risk the other university students stealing the girl away from him (whereas he didn't think the young guy would be able to). This plays into the above point because under different circumstances he probably would have never even associated with him and therefore never would never have considered him for the job.

comment:
5:37 That's an interesting point, it made me realize that we see that a lot in the movie. Son ki-woo hiding beneath the rich girl's bed, the Kims hiding beneath the table as the parks are having sex above them. Having to endure the degradation of them talking about the father's smell and being turned on by the daughter's underwear. Sitting through that scene was so mortifying, I can't imagine what actually being there and for the whole thing would have felt like. The contrast between those trying to survive beneath them and those enjoying something frivolous like perverted sex right above them also struck me (and then having to continue business as usual while pretending nothing happened).
And then there's of course those living in the basement beneath them, the parks completely oblivious to its existence and their existence, just as they are oblivious to those living in half-basements, enduring floods and practically living in the sewage(again symbolic to something beneath us that we ignore in everyday life, but allows us a safer, cleaner life above), while they enjoy the luxury of their isolation on their house on the hill.
Another interesting thing about this is how the kims are desperate to keep the couple in the basement a locked secret while they walk above them, pretending to belong. Very symbolic to their situation and society in general and also relates back to what you pointed out about the struggle between the poor and poorer.

8:33 In another video about the movie someone pointed out that they expect them not to cross the line but constantly cross the line themselves. Like when they promptly ask them to join the birthday party, not really caring for their opinion or when mister kim is asked by mister park to perform for their child in a silly costume even though he clearly doesn't want to and it isn't his job.

What's really shocking about this movie to me is two things, the first is that the rich and the general public have not only learnt nothing after this, but never even realized what it is that took place the entire time. They'll probably continue living just thinking they were some crazy poor people and that poor people can't be trusted. They wouldn't care the daughter died, that the kims were injured, and one ended up trapped in a basement, or why. The father will never know there was a man living in a basement beneath him for years who admired him, and none of it will matter.
The second thing is that there was no happy ending for the kims, and wealth remained unobtainable, the final scene where it was presented as an illusion created the same sense of false hope for the audience as for the kims, only to then break it, leaving us in bleak basements and half-basements of false yearning, the kims worse off than before, in different states of ruin, from death to being locked up and torn apart, to being on the verge of insanity.

comment:
I think the movie is hugely misinterpreted by a lot of people - unfortunately as well in this video, although I liked it as food for thought. Parasite of course critiques modern society and decreasing social mobility. But it does not critique captialism per se. Parasite doesn't construct a class conflict, it instead shows (yes, like you said in your video) the ignorance of the rich for the struggles of the poor and the fighting between the poor to achieve the status of the rich. But it doesn't critique the system as well, it just shows that there is no way to move up in socioeconomic status. But there's an important distinction between critiquing this and constructing class conflict. Parasite shows the moral ambiguity of both, the Kims and the Parks, they're both Parasites to each other. The takeaway of the film is basically, that, within the system, the rich should be interested in enabling social mobility - of which the visual symbol of stairs is very present in the film - and open their eyes for the struggles of the poor in order to continue living their lifestyle. Because ultimately, the Parks pay the price for their ignorance - of course the Kims do as well. Both are losers of the increasing divide and the fight for a better socioeconomic status. I also think that this interpretation better fits the situation in South Korea as well as Bong Joon-ho's other work. (SPOILER) In Snowpiercer, for example, there is a big revolution at the end of the movie, the system is overthrown. But the result is, that the train derails and everybody dies at last. Everybody loses. We also have to interpret Bong's works with the current political landscape of South Korea in mind. Yes, there is a big divide between rich and poor, yes, there are no big safety nets for people like social systems in Europe (where I am from, btw). But there is also the very real negative example of a different economic system nearby: North Korea. Capitalism is engrained in South Korea and it is the main reason for the stellar rise of the country since the Korean War. Capitalism is not a bad "ideology" in South Korea, instead the current, negative development of capitalism proves dangerous for society, and this is what Parasite essentially critiques. Capitalism is neither bad nor good, it is essentially empty and what people make of it. South Korea has seen what good Capitalism can do, so Bongs Films would be far from critizising this very system and constructing a class conflict that any class can win and profit of.
I think Parasite is often misunderstood especially in countries like the US where there is a lack of social security systems or basic social democratic policy. But Parasite does not critique the system of capitalism itself, it does not pit two classes against each other, and when it does, it shows that no one can benefit from overthrowing the system or any sort of revolutionary act. At least that is my interpretation, and I personally think (of course I am biased) that I do have the arguments to support my interpretation here.

comment: I like this film because it doesn‚Äôt really take sides ‚Äî the Kims justify their heinous acts of social destruction that kill those equally impoverished and ultimately harms them as well by persuading themselves that only the rich can be just anyway, while the Parks are entirely oblivious and callous towards their plight, contributing as well to the tragedies that unfold. The smell could be a reflection of the miserable lives of the poor, but it may also be the stench of evil minds trying to take advantage of kindness. Another point I think could be raised is that maybe the Parks are nouveau rich themselves. Why would they know the smell of the subway and love the more ‚Äúcommon‚Äù food of jjapaguri that isn‚Äôt really associated with the rich? Perhaps it‚Äôs showing how the rich are equally inelegant and lacking decorum deep down, but maybe it reflects how they managed to preserve their innocence as they climbed up from a much less affluent environment themselves, or maybe scarier yet, how this entire movie could be a cycle, meaning that the Kims could have acted just like the Parks if they climbed into their position, just as forgetful of their past. All in all, I feel the movie does a very nice job of illuminating both sides of the argument.

comment: The sociological analysis starting at min 4 of your video is pretty good, however I would disagree with some of the assumptions. While it is important to raise issues of poverty and exploitation, I think its equally important to keep in mind the context, Korean society is much less meritocratic than western societies, throughout the film the director shows us just how capable the family acting as servants really are, often showing them as more capable than the Parks.  However,  the core issues in the U.S. and europe are not the same, while some capable people are certainly excluded from growth and wealth, the reasons for their exclusion have more to do with low labour mobility (i.e. the difficulty and cost of moving to cities where they could earn more) and the high cost of living in economically vibrant areas. With regards to Apple's exploitation of Foxconn factory workers I agree that bad working conditions should be corrected, but it is equally important to consider how literally millions of chinese farm workers went form struggling to feed themselves, to having access to education and opportunity, please read Factory girls, its a great account of the individuals we tend to look down on in the west, it shows just how creative, hard working, and ambitious these people are, and more importantly how these factory jobs enabled them to fulfil their dreams, and lead happier lives. To summarise: I agree with the overall gist of your argument, but I urge you to include more nuance and not use cliches to gloss over what are complex multi-factorial issues.

comment: Hey there, I agree. I had 30 followers when I made this video and never imagined it would be seen by such a wide audience. If I could go back, I would definitely make the video more culturally specific and contextualize the current situation in South Korea. In regards to the factories - I am aware that the advent of factory work has brought many of these people out of acute poverty, but there is still no excuse for why they are paid so little for the solid labour they do given what the people at the top are making. Unfortunately I squeezed these arguments into a video that was digestible for a mainstream audience, but if I could go back I would try and be more nuanced about it.

comment:
Kevin I'm sorry for my lateness but "Rich Bad; Poor Good" isn't the message of the movie, nowhere close. Never once does the movie endorse either side in which both sides are represented from the Parks and the Kims. comment: Well done. Needed more so than ever! Cool capitalism started, as far as I am concerned, when we all started wearing T shirts with the logos of companies considered cool, back in the '70's, the rise of maga manufacturers. We may not be able to afford the products but we can consider ourselves cool by being walking billboards for such companies. How much is Parasite about, 'survival of the fitess?' No revolution shown, but what is the definition of revolution, blood is let and people are killed. In Western countries inequality is obvious if people chose to see it! Governments refuse to see it, in Canada PM, in a photo op, gives out winter coats to refugees but nothing to Canadians sleeping on concrete in major Canadian cities during the heat of the summer or freezing cool of winter. In former third world countries, you have the rich living in highrise apartments and people living in carboard boxes as neighbours. A contrast that say we don't all rise together. This comparison is becoming more so in the West. A couple of decades ago the thought was, the distance of standard of living  between the first world countries and the third world was getting wider. Now the distances within each country between the haves and the have nots is getting wider and wider.

comment:
Parasite is a hopelessly naive and simplistic movie. The so-called "elite" class is not monolithic. It is heavily stratified with constant movement, conflict and - more often than people are willing to admit - violence at the interfaces. If this were anything approaching reality the rich family would be as concerned with holding on to their position and/or attempting to ascend the next rung of the ladder as the poor one. I'm not sure how much you have read of people like Gramsci but given the context into which you've embedded the quote I question whether you've understood any it. I see you have quoted Doug Kellner who I know from way back in Austin (before he came to the conclusion that if you can't beat them - join them). Unless he has changed a great deal since he became all "civilised" I'd argue he'd take a rather jaundiced view of Bong - who affects to be a critical observer outside the socio-political framework but whether he understands it or not ("We allow you to make the films in which you say what you like BECAUSE we like what you say") in his attempts to undermine societal norms he simply re-enforces them.


I mean, faced with being returned to a "free" but precivilised age as his protagonists are at the end of Snowpiercer after they overthrow the tyranny of the train most people living today (who could scarcely survive twenty four hours in nature no matter how many episodes of Bear Grylls they've watched) wouldn't think twice about leaving - regardless of their miserable existence. And yet Bong is presenting a completely bogus false dichotomy which some might argue serves little purpose but to prop up the status quo.

By the way - with the exception of a half-a-dozen families whose heritage can be traced all the way back to the Crusades just about everyone in the elite class at some point began scratching out a living at the very bottom rungs of the ladder. This pathway has always existed - and it always shall. Indeed in countries such as the United States, Britain and France sufficiently talented members of the working class are feted and recruited (usually within the University/High School system) and fast-tracked into positions of responsibility (think of Richard Nixon or John Major). Contrary to your argument it has never been difficult to accrue wealth. It's comforting to pin the blame entirely on the upper elites for conspiring at every turn to thwart progress toward the wealth and happiness you unquestionably deserve when the reality is you chose not to pursue this end because the cost was too high. When I say "cost" I'm not talking about enthusiasm, labour or money. I'm talking about the cost to your humanity - or to use religious terminology - your immortal soul. And once you step over that line there's no going back. "Successful" people have the capacity to compartmentalise this cost and continue to function. But most people can't. There have been many opportunities in my life when I have turned down opportunities to make a great deal more money because I knew I couldn't live with the memory of screwing people over. An example of a far more sophisticated film (despite one or two flaws) which recognises this reality is David O. Russell's "Joy".

comment: This is a weird interpretation of Parasite.  There are very few Marxists in SKorea.  I doubt the director was thinking along the line of the Marxist interpretation of this film as Broey Deschanel suggests.  Bong was probably thinking of something more practical and mundane as the fact that in Korea, particularly in Seoul, young people cannot hope to ever own their own homes, making it difficult for them to marry, have kids, and have a family.  Also, what is missing in the subtitle translation is the fact that Korean is a polite language.  This is an aspect of the movie translation that's gone totally missing.  In polite languages such as Korean and Japanese, language presupposes a whole host of social expectations.  In the subtitle translation, this aspect of social expectation is totally lost, as there's no such equivalency in the English language.  When watching the movie in Korean, it is Mr. Park's family who dare not "cross the line."  Mr. Park's entire family shows proper respect for Mr. Kim's family members (in Korean).  What is happening in a consumer-oriented society, this traditional value of basic human decency is increasingly becoming blurred.

comment: This movie is more about members of the working class fighting each other instead of working together. When I thought the movie was about rich vs poor, I didn't like it because it didn't make much sense. The Kim family is not likable at all. They're lazy (25% defect rate folding pizza boxes) and heartless. They get the chauffeur and housekeeper fired with little remorse. They don't care that they left the housekeeper for dead in the basement. When I thought this was rich vs poor class warfare it didn't make sense because the poor are pictured in such a terrible light. But when you see it more as the cruelty of the poor towards each other in their fright for scraps from the rich, it makes more sense. And yes, this is very much a Marxist movie that urges the working class to unite instead of fighting each other.

comment:
@Jared G. did you watch the movie? Because it seems that you missed up the point entirely.
I don't know how you would get from the movie that the people didn't want to work hard to get a better life.
With the sister, she had the talent and she could teach, but being she didn't have the connections or the money to get a chance. Neither did the brother, who did very well in school but cannot go to university. The kids they were tutoring were just born into wealth the same way they were born into poverty. And so by random luck one set of kids have access to the best schools (he can pay the fees or he could literally pay their way in or they could get a leg up in applications if their parents are important enough or donate enough money to the school) and tutors and resources. If they want an internship their dad can connect them and they can afford to work it unpaid, if they want to start a business he can lend them a few million dollars or probably has good credit. They can get the right clothes to impress at an interview, they were probably able to prep or have powerful connected people to represent them. They know all the unwritten laws about how to behave in corporate spaces.
And if you start a business venture how are you going to make a million? Someone has to be able to work for you, right? Someone has to be the maid cleaning or the security guard otherwise you'd never increase in scale enough to drag yourself out of your social class. And should those people then live miserably and be disadvantaged in most areas of life? Why is their (the kids in the movie) ability to participate in the so-called meritocracy hindered?
These are the questions Parasite invites us to ask.
Everyone loves a good story about someone making it big but it is incredibly naive to think that all you need to succeed is willpower and work ethic. It's a start and a crucial part of it BUT being wealthy or having a wealthy background gives an unimaginable boost to our aspirations. There is a world of difference between how much hard work Oprah had to do versus a Kylie Jenner to make their first billion.

comment: qwdfvbtyhjm iklkjuy You're literally ignoring the actual meaning behind those phrases. They do not mean "Go work in the coal mines or clean floors for 11 hours a day and someone will give you a million dollars". What they actually LITERALLY apply to is using whatever resources you have available to get to a point where you can climb to the top. Maybe starting your own business venture or investing for example. Think of it like a car and a rocket ship. You're expecting someone to carry you to space in a car, even though you didn't wanna put in the work and risk everything to build a rocket ship. comment: This review is so rife with imposition of the reviewer's own biases and a priori assumptions that it truly astonished me. Wow. The poor family's "harsh society?" There's nothing in the film to suggest that the society they live in is harsh, though what is established early on is that the poor family has entrenched itself in poverty by the choices they relate and demonstrate, including laziness, dishonesty, lack of perseverance, lack of respect for others, and willful lack of education, etc, even praising the daughter's cleverness such that she'd make a great con artist.  It's simply not established in the film that they are victims of anything but their own devices: Right out of the gate the poor father relates how many jobs he's had, been unwilling to keep, and so apparently maintained his family's poverty, as well as what he has modeled for his children who repeat the pattern. As the father later says, he doesn't have a plan because plans go wrong, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy.  Or what about another of the reviewer's impositions: The Park family is leeching off of the poor people too?! How? By hiring them to perform a service and paying them to do it? (Is this reviewer leeching off of YouTube?) My gosh, talk about imposition of snobbish, elitist assumptions external to the film and then, as sure as the sun will rise, proffering her clear preference for socialism supported by a vapid critique of capitalism that affirms the subtext of her review. Truly mind-boggling this review.  Sorry, but the reviewer's assessment is "not on the page."

comment:
I thought it was interesting how the family living in the sub-basement still see themselves as superior to the family living in the basement (like the father blaming the man for living there without a plan while he himself famously never makes a plan). Is that a reference to people considering themselves middle class while the middle class has been collapsing for years into lower class? From the interior of the sub-basement one would think they were not always a poor family, despite the father being constantly compared to a bug.
Another two interesting points that I saw in another video: the cinematography often uses physical lines (glass panes, corners of the room, and other architectural elements) to visually seperate the Park's from their servants. Watch it again and it's hard to miss. Also, I found it very interesting that somebody mentioned the little boy's obsession with Native Americans. Could this be a reference to how the Park family is completely oblivious to those scheming to invade their territory?


This movie has so many layers, it will occupy my mind for a while. Although it did bother me that at times the social commentary seemed to overrule common sense. Like how when the rich parents lay down on the couch and the poor family is hiding under the table, he smells the father rather than all the bottles of alcohol they broke half an hour earlier. And the plan at the end might seem like a wonderful way of conveying the broken American dream, but wouldn't he just go and help his father escape the next night rather than going through some outlandish and abstract plan?

comment:
This whole hegemony argument is debunked if adequate social mobility exists.
To uncover tangible solutions to the class divide we should be searching for all the factors prohibiting social mobility. The only concrete factor provided is (13:13) stagnant wages <- agreed, let's fix this
> Another would be the real hegemony, crony regulations
Often it's the largest corporations that will lobby for more. late capitalism The greatest trick bureaucrats ever pulled was to convince the uninformed that more authoritarianism is good (11:45). Big Business close the door to success behind them by lobbying bureaucrats for more and more crony protectionist permits (ex: taxi medallion, hairstylist license). They know entrepreneurs and smaller businesses with fewer resources would be tied down. I can't understate how vibrant the economy would be were it not for these entry hazards.
Economy = autonomy of the people.
The more open the field is,
the more valuable merit becomes,
which anyone can earn. <- this is the society that we should foster; one filled with scholarly, creative, inventive, 'go-getters' stuffing the world with materialized bright new ideas; not one with non-ending paranoia with convenient blanket discrimination against the perceived 'haves'

Bong explained that the stone floating was a representation of Ki-Woo‚Äôs ‚Äòhallucination‚Äô, and it was his effort to convey the message that Ki-Woo still clutching onto the hopes of climbing the social ladder. comment:
Our societies have become like a hierarchal pyramid. We support those of higher station out of fear that if we do not we will be relegated to an even lower position within the pyramid. We are forced to defend the hierarchal structure of our society that subjugate us when we are forced to defend our position within the hierarchy from those below us.

But we still have a choice. We could do away with a pyramid like hierarchy and treat each other as equals and do away with hierarchical social structures altogether. To do so would mean we would not only have to remove those above us from power, we would have to stop defending our own position with in it. It‚Äôs our own greed (to move up in the hierarchy) and fear (of being at the mercy of others with more power) that‚Äôs keeping the hierarchy intact.

It‚Äôs like the person who thinks to their self ‚ÄúThat one person over there has 5 houses and 10 sport cars all to their selves. That‚Äôs not fair! I want that privilege. Who do I have to destroy to get it?‚Äù, as he drives by (in an average car) A man who can‚Äôt make enough money (no matter how hard he works) to afford a home or a car or decent food to eat. And so he votes against helping his fellow man less he gets relegated to an even lower position in the hierarchy.

comment: I mean, Foxconn is contracted by many other tech giants to build their products too, to focus solely on Apple is a moot point. I have relatives that live in Hong Kong, who were up in Shenzhen to work at those factory campuses. The socioeconomic condition means that they believe the work they endure is a fact of life. It is highly exaggerated by the west of being close to 'slave labour' when the skill level of work is relative to how they are paid. A lot of the western criticism does not take into consideration that standard of living and affordability is very different to the west and people live in relative comfort, not so concerned about being 'in poverty'. The scandals at Foxconn only picked up and escalated in the media when locals started to pick up that the conditions were not to a 'western standard' and workers started to develop mental health symptoms by way of exposure. As an inductive example, one of my cousins that worked at the campus that focused mainly on Microsoft products like keyboards and mice, saved enough to travel a bit with his girlfriend. This was his first time going overseas, and to Australia in fact. He returned, and couldn't last in the same job for more than two months and started developing symptoms of depression shortly after. The other cousin was actually stationed at one of the Foxconn factories that assembled for Apple. I used to remember him complaining about some of his fellow workers would slack off and hold up their entire line and get hated on by that whole team. You don't hear anything about about these things in the west. It's more local media stuff. The west is focused on pushing class-warfare, and profiting from the lower, middle-class outrage. Anyway, my cousin stayed there for about 3 years and got promoted to supervisor and is now a line manager. I guess the first example was similar to how the Kims were generally content with their living arrangement, until they were given a glimpse of the outside, their mentality of class had shifted, it's as though they cannot go back. The Parks were ignorant, while the Kims were hyperaware of this class divide.

comment:
I wouldn't say we 'created' these structures so much as they were bound to evolve to the point that they're now at in the way that they have. These structures and systems are as much a part of nature as anything else.

'Capitalism' by any other name is a system that most closely mirrors our natural propensity towards taking advantage of other living beings and technologies to secure our own safety/ meet our own needs and satisfy our own goals and desires.



It seems to me that all lasting social systems throughout history have reflected, and will inevitably continue to reflect this unfortunate reality (barring some significant paradigm shifting advancement in technology that renders resource inequalities, sexual competition and social hierarchies a thing of the past, that is. Whether that be virtual worlds or some kind of singularity with AI or something else altogether...?).

comment:
I'd like to add some thing myself
They might be far fetched but this movie gives us a lot of space to do so.
1) Regarding the rich mother falling asleep in two random moments. This might be a mocking because she does nothing and still falls asleep, while the working class is tired so people fall asleep from lack of it or she is so bored she has nothing to do, that she falls asleep again in contrary to others that have too much to do and thus get exhausted.
2) Again this might be far fetched but it's just my point of view. The man in the basement, the one that has been there for 4 years is a very good representation of North Korea. He lives so close to the rich ones, yet they don't know him at all because he is hidden there, far from the rest of the world. He is eating barely enough to survive yet still feels thankful for Mr. Park who is 'feeding' him yet Mr. Park doesn't even know him. His life's purpose is to do use light patterns as an ode to his greatness. The fact that his wife did a news reporter from N.Korea and did it so well, according to him, further proves those two are connected.
3) The main character (the poor son) is eventually most of us. Capitalism promises that by hard work, everyone will be able to succeed. Just like the rest of us, he wants to work well and make money, to get his dad out of there. To 'raise' him, from the basement to the top. We all want a better future for our parents, to please them for everything they've given us. Especially in Korea, as far as I know, kids tend to be close with their parents even when they get older. However, the son never makes it. His son won't make it as well. and so on and so on. Unlike Capitalism's promise, it's a state that can hardly change.
4) The boundaries about the rich father what talking about. It gives me goosebumbs to think that he said something along the lines of 'Mr Kim has been close to crossing the line but never does so' yet at the end of the movie he does, comes really close to him, in the most aggressive way possible. What a masterpiece this movie was!

No. Ki-Taek didn‚Äôt work for Geun-Se. They both started their own businesses when the Taiwan Cake boom started in Korea in 2016, and they both went down when a tv program falsely claimed that the cakes contained ingredients harmful to consumers and everyone started boycotting the cakes.

comment: Cultural Hegemony doesn't exist in a place where your culture isn't predominant. Hence why more advanced societies in the past prefer colonizing to force people who they can coerce to believe their culture, or eradicate people who refuses to believe or adapt to their cultural standards. Nowadays, that cultural subjugation applies to technology and its rampant usage of it. comment:
This anatomy only fits in Korean and other Asian countries where the law of demand and supply is not in favour of the poor. Opportunities are fewer where people who are more competent are so many, make the chance of becoming rich is really hard. Ki-woo (the Kim's son) is really competent but he's doesn't have the opportunity that he needs to get into college.


However, this is a whole different story in the States and other first World western countries where opportunities are plenty and the only thing you need to do is to work hard. I've seen so many Vietnamese oversee people who got richer despite the poor qualifications they have back in Vietnam. The reasons they can earn more is because the opportunities they have plus the hard work they do in the State that get them to that position. I live in Australia and I can survive with a waiter job here at minimum wage of $23 AUD/hour. I would say capitalism benefits from China's communism with the low wage they have to pay for workers over there, but if you are living under the capitalism of a first World country and you're still poor, it's on you.

comment:
Hi everyone! Wow thank you so much for all the kind comments it's really cool to see people engaging with the video :) I just wanted to address two things: 1) I apologize if my skin whitening example came off as Eurocentric. I should have acknowledged that the aspiration for paleness in certain places has deep historical/cultural roots. However, I used that example because the desire for whiter skin is not just limited to East Asia, and there is no way that this can be divorced from a long history of colonialism that has impacted so many cultures around the world - not to mention contemporary beauty standards promoted through global mass media. I myself am half Guyanese, and the colourism that exists in our culture is historical, but it is also very much entangled with Eurocentrism. 2) Many people have argued that capitalism is at least better than its alternative: communism. I never once mentioned communism in this video and I made an effort to specify that I'm talking about neoliberal/late capitalism. I (personally) believe more government intervention and a more robust social safety net is a viable answer to an untethered and deregulated free market system. The Scandinavian countries are a great example - and if you're looking for somewhere more diverse - even Canada (although it's far from perfect) has a pretty strong social system. Corporations need to be held more accountable and should never have more power than a government in my opinion. Anyway - thank you all for the support, I really appreciate it! :) I hope to make videos more frequently in the future!


Also - I know my audio is iffy but the constant comments about it are a little melodramatic. I really don't think my audio quality is an insult to the director or cinema at large, but whatever do you I guess!


Edit: forgot to pin this! hope it clarifies some stuff!

comment: What's sad is that there is no form of system better for our society than capitalism. Of course, modern capitalism combines some elements of socialism as well through provision of various welfare benefits and other devices that act to more evenly level the playing field and soften the lower edge of society. However, social inequality will always remain, because we are all born unequally. What's also meaningful about this movie is that there is no real antagonist. It's not overtly a movie about the lower class revolting against the rich upper class. If anyone feels the movie was about that, that's a misunderstanding of the movie. It depicts the darkness of social inequality without necessarily condemning the winners of our capitalist society. The fact that there is really no one to blame or attack in the movie makes it even more tragic.

comment:
While I loved the film, I don't particularly like how everyone is tearing into the very core of capitalism as if it isn't actually more beneficial to society as, lets say, communism. But while I feel strongly about that, that is not to say that capitalism doesn't triumph over communism in SOME of the worst ways; and that being harsh status difference that separates the rich from the poor. Most middle class people are likely to stay at their staus, but have a chance at becoming rich, while having a slim chance of landing in poverty, while most impoverished people are stuck. I feel like this movie did highlight why the impoverished suffer from being so stagnant, because while they may be skilled, their inability to afford school or (mostly) college can leave them where they are until someone along the line breaks off from the chain.

But again, I don't think it's black and white. Capitalism isn't inherently evil, but I don't believe there is such a thing as a perfect system either. Again though, as much as I am for capitalism, I feel like this movie did such a good job at pointing at many facets of economic status in society. Like, while there may not have been a middle class family in the mix, I do believe that Min, the friend who gave Ki-woo that tutoring job, may have been the representation for that. I think it's safe to assume that he was that 'path' for Ki-woo to reach higher, because as most middle class people, he has the opportunity to either stay where he is or become richer, and in this case he granted his friends entire family the chance to become higher just because of something simple as posing as a college tutor, which Ki-woo probably couldn't get into for whatever reasons (and this is just an assumption, but I'm pretty sure that most colleges in Korea (I think) deeply scrutinize what school you came from to determine if you should be a student at their college. comment:
The funniest part of the movie for me is how the rich are assumed to be higher-up in terms of social darwinism, how you're trained to just assume that they're simply better people who deserve their positions and that they're definitely better and put in more labor than the lazy poor people, but in actuality it is the poor family that both out-labors the rich and out-smarts them. The poor are the alphas, the rich are the betas, and if their economic roles were reversed the Parks would probably starve in the streets.
I know a person who's deeply indoctrinated into the Capitalist mindset. It is never the fault of the corporation, or the business, it's always either the government or poor people, expect when the government helps the rich, then it's fine, but if it even thinks of helping the poor riots should break out in the streets. I know it should terrify me, but the fact that this person wouldn't get even a whiff of this message is hilarious to me. They are the basement dweller that's bashing their brains in like a trained dog in a vain attempt to please their superior, who they only assume is superior due to their status.
The movie's tone might change in the second half, but in a certain sense, it's still a comedy trough and trough.

comment:
It‚Äôs terrifying because it is the kind of reality we live in and it appears that it is something that we cannot (and even if we can, we are still unwilling to) change.

Humans may be superior in intellect among all living species in this planet and, hence, can easily outsmart other living things in order to survive and even reign supreme in the biological food chain, we have one major flaw that nature instilled in us to ensure of our eventual extinction‚ÄîGREED.

We created a social system where living in excess seems to be the ideal lifestyle. We greed for wealth beyond the sufficient amount for us to survive or live a decent life so we can afford to buy more and more stuff we don‚Äôt actually need. In turn, we leach off of mother nature to create/manufacture products in excess of what‚Äôs necessary at the expense of our natural and human resources leaving tons and tons of waste that can‚Äôt be naturally degraded. And voila! We have our governments to ensure that everything is under control and that this is how things are supposed to work out.

While we think that we‚Äôre living life to the fullest by having more than what we need at an instant, we remain oblivious to parts of the world that continue to have too little to survive...and are being maintained that way so the other half could live a totally opposite life. Worse is even if we‚Äôre aware of such inequities and injustice, we feel it to be beyond our grasp to change or that it simply has nothing to do with us.

We created poverty, wars, diseases and climate change. And in the end, those who have less are the ones who are more unprotected from all of it. And we know for a fact that the trend has always been putting majority of the world‚Äôs wealth to a handful and leaving the rest divided among billions of others.

Mother Earth doesn‚Äôt need a more superior species to keep humans under control. We created that monster ourselves.

WE ARE OUR OWN PARASITES. And boy! We are unforgiving.

comment: In my opinion  "Parasite" is one of the best movies in the last decade, and this analysis is simply brilliant, I agree 100% that every class lives through expenses of the other and what I loved the most is that the director neither idealize the Kim's nor condemn the Parks, is a very objective view with characters that have both virtues and defaults like real human beings, thank you so much for this contribution, however I think blaming capitalism per se for some of the problems the film points out is too symplistic and I don't see that's Bong Jo's intention. There are a lot of things that are not desirable in modern society however I have to ask this: what economic system is a better alternative ?? Socialism also has an upper class gathered in the dominant party. Myself as an inhabitant from a latin american country where state interventionism is still very strong I can tell you that politics which are oriented to a socialist model are everything but succesfull in order to improve people's lives, my dad grew up in a country without foreign companies around, without free market awareness and again in a land ruled by strong statism policies... he was miserable, he literally spent all his childhood living in a paperboard house and eating only twice a day, he had to  do all type of minor services by himself to afford his school and finally after many years of struggle he was in a much better situation however during his productive years there weren't many opportunities unless you were a friend of a politician, that was before we were "invaded" by neoliberalist policies.  There will always be better-paid jobs than others, simply because we as a society value unique talent more than low-skilled labor, I mean I agree we should be awared about social injustice and we can do a lot more to close the barriers but  I've worked in the filming industry and in a production even if it's small there are hundreds of people involved and I'm sure Mr. Bong Joon Ho has no remorse of him or his main actors earning more money than those others who had a lesser role by making his films besides he lives in a world where he doesn't have to be part of the top 1000 billionaires to enjoy a very decent level of life.  It's the way it is, as Churchill said: "capitalism is the worst system except all others"

comment:
There are more choices than communism and high-inequality corporatism. The problems in the movie were how poor the Kims are, how difficult it is to escape poverty despite opening businesses like the cake shop, that 500 university graduates apply to be a security guard, etc. You can solve these without the USSR.

Scandinavian social-welfare capitalism ensures it's easier to work your way up and the poorest live better lives. More people can afford university, your life isn't ruined if your business goes bust, and it's easier to be an entrepreneur who gives other people jobs.

comment:
Great to see someone mentioning Gramsci. I think we can divide this film in two big moments regarding class relations: 1- the lower class family that's stuck in poverty trying to reach the top by all means possible. This isn't possible neither by hardworking or cheating or even by reproducing the same classist agression/competition with members of their own class (the previous maid and her husband) . 2- The family members realizing that they do not belong in the healthy environment and upper class mannerisms, leading to class consciousness (each member of the poor family reacts to it differently).

You did a great job in the video, congratulations!

comment:
Excellent! What insightful analysis and thorough research! There's one thought I wanted to express, though: I feel like the cultural hegemony that the Kims have bought into has less to do with worshiping the upper class (I would argue that they look down on the Parks, and see them as nice but foolish) and more to do with their own pride. They've had a taste of what it's like to have status and money, and now they will not let go of it, no matter what. Even if it means killing fellow workers, they will keep climbing the "social staircase" (notice the visual metaphor in the film of the two families racing to the top of the bunker stairs, dragging each other down). In this sense, I believe capitalism has taught them not to be content with servitude, but to claw their way to the top.

I actually am writing a paper on this as my college integrative project (incorporating Marx and Rousseau), so it's definitely good to see other folks doing their research and finding the deeper meanings behind Parasite! What a fantastic film, truly. I will check out the sources you quoted and see if I can incorporate them in my bibliography.

comment: @Broey Deschanel Oh yes definitely there is a bit of a love-hate dynamic going on between  the two families. The Kims believe themselves to be better than the Parks on some level, because they are smarter, or at least more wily. On the other hand, they are jealous of the Parks' wealth and status. They've seen the privileged lifestyle of this bourgeois family and want it for themselves. This is what leads the Kims to thinking of the house as "their house," even though it will never actually be theirs. They feel entitled to it because they are starting to believe they can integrate into the world of the Parks (through the means of Kiwoo marrying Dahye). So on some level they hate these snobby rich people. But they also want to be them, as we see with Kiwoo's fantasy at the end. No matter what, money always corrupts. Even though the poor may despise the rich, they still desire that lifestyle for themselves (which is hypocritical of course, but very human).

comment: First, I would like to say wow, this analysis took a lot of time and research which is highly commendable. However, because you are analyzing this movie from a very limited framework, you have missed out on the overall theme of this movie which isn't about capitalism, though it does play a part in it. It's easy to get stuck in this black and white mindset where society is constructed to keep rich people at the top and poor people at the bottom. Rich people are simply benefiting from a capitalistic system and poor people can never rise to the top. This simply isn't factually true. If you took less time looking over theories and more time looking at the research data you would see that the facts point to a different narrative. For example, intelligence is a bigger factor of success than socio economic status. In other words, a rich person born in poverty has a higher chance of becoming richer than a person of lesser intelligence born in wealth. There seems to be a wide variety of factors and there still needs to be more research. However, from what we do know, there are a few components that are seemingly crucial. One, you need to have emotional intelligence in order to take risks such as starting your own business. That means, having a stable supportive social support network so when you fail, you can keep going and learning from your mistakes. Not having a stable emotional support group as well as a poor emotional well being will greatly stifle your ability to do well. Second, you need to have the right personality. People who are open, disagreeable, and conscientious tends to make more money than those who aren't. In order words, you need to have an entrepreneurial mindset in order to attain a lot of wealth. If you are interested in studying and helping people instead of making money, then you won't make a lot of money because that isn't your goal. And of course, intelligence is probably the biggest predictor of wealth and unfortunately, this disadvantage is not socially constructed but naturally imposed. So in the end, yes, there is a clear inequality between rich and poor in modern capitalistic societies such as America but it seems to be inherited in natural injustices rather than socially constructed injustices. But even if you aren't intelligent, nor have the right personality to break into the 1%, it doesn't mean you can't live a comfortable and happy life because you don't need to smart or rich to be happy and happiness is a better end to strive for.
