comment: I would have to disagree. Just because someone is intelligent does not guarantee they can climb the socio-economic ladder. You can see it in the film itself - Ki-Woo and Ki-Jeung are shown to be highly skilled and intelligent individuals, but neither of them is able to escape their socioeconomic situation. They stand in complete opposition to someone like (forgive me) Donald Trump, who is by no means an objectively intelligent individual, yet who amassed an empire based on economic status and connections alone. There are always external factors at play - did you parents have time to support and encourage your education? are you able to afford a better education? does your school have the resources/funding to provide adequate learning? does your government offer adequate funding? do you have to forgo your ambitions to take care of relatives? All of these combine to disadvantage someone from attaining higher socioeconomic status - wealth cannot be equated to innate biological qualities. Of course it's a socially constructed injustice, economic wealth itself is a manmade thing.

comment:
Thoughtful video that engages with the ideas and theories with great enthusiasm. I always enjoy these. Well edited, well argued. Brisk pace and gets large concepts across in an efficient way. This movie was terrific.

Let's go on a trip together. There's a number of things that prevented me from buying into an anlysis of this movie that is primarily sociological or economic. One is, if killing Mr. Park was a justifiable action according to this video's thesis, i.e. the wrongful oppression of many through cool capitalism and cultural hegemony which should be defied, how do we explain Mr. Kim's remorse and shellshock afterward?

There's a hint of Crime and Punishment in here which brings the movie beyond economic and sociological interpretation. Namely the individual psychology and personal struggle with aforementioned structures, cool capitalism, cultural hegemony, and with murder, personal corruption, exploitation of others, etc. Mr. Kim's human reaction to murder goes beyond economic and cultural analysis. The mere fact of being human confounds rational justifications. If cool capitalism and cultural hegemony are so wrong and deserve to be rebelled against, then why doesn't Mr. Kim revel in his victory? Because life is so much deeper than economic or sociological analyses. And I think, despite Bong's overt interpretations of his own film, that this movie argues that point at its core.

While I agree that there is a fearsome takeaway from this movie, I don't think the emphasis is placed on theoretical structures. Those things are pervasive in the movie and certainly frame it, but they take a backseat to the characters and the importance of personal conduct in the face of economic or social circumstances.

The movie contains, oddly, an archetypal hero myth structure in the falling action. The hero rescues his father from the underground, or at least aspires to do so. This is a reference to the power of the individual and how he can rejuvenate society by upright action. This points to a significant shift in Kevin's personality that suggests, retroactively, that the movie was foremost about Kevin's psychological journey and personal development, rather than an explication of economic and sociological concepts. I won't go into any great depth about this line of argumentation because of the limits of this format. But it's something to consider on your own if you've made it to the end of this comment.

comment:
@elliphant21

Korea's economic situation is nothing short of a disaster. So shortly after its miraculous rise in wealth, it is now projected to enter permanent economic recession similar to Japan. Corruption plays a big role, as well as an aging demography and overdependance upon international trade. Nothing you've brought up is false. Kiwoo may never be able to realize his explicit noble aspiration. In fact, he most certainly won't.

That lies outside my argument, however. I did not say he would be able to rescue his father. I said that he had experienced a personality shift that, maybe for the first time in his life, has lifted his eyes UP, changed his target to one that rises UP. There are many small steps to take, and along that steep and difficult path upwards, there is potential for personality growth and psychological development.

I'll repeat my point. The economic analysis which you've put forward does not fully encompass Kiwoo's humanity. It's a cliche, but it rings true here: money does not buy happiness. Marcus Aurelius wrote, "the happiness of your life depends on the quality of your thoughts." Kiwoo's thoughts--more, his entire perspective--has changed and put him on an upward trajectory. Again, upward in terms of his character and personal development. This brings in the symbol in the movie, the scholar's rock. Does it represent wealth? Or the qualities that make up a wealthy character? Kiwoo obsesses over this symbol throughout the movie and he understands it in the end.

There are many people like the Kims aiming DOWN. What happens when enough people, like Kiwoo, stop? The movie leaves this question hanging open.

comment: ArtificialxSky you bring up some good points however, I think kiwoo‚Äôs aspiration to get rich in order to rescue his father is actually one of the most heartbreaking parts of the movie. bong said in an interview that it would take kiwoo 564 years to work and save enough to buy that house, which shows just how broken our socioeconomic system is. it seems reasonable that someone should be able to get out of poverty from their hard work alone, but in reality kiwoo is powerless against capitalistic society and will be stuck in the same metaphorical basement apartment until he dies. this myth of upward mobility only exists in our society so that the poor will continue to have hope in the system that exploits their labor and eventually kills them. this hope for future upward mobility upholds the system because the lower class is too busy trying to survive and get out of poverty to have an effective revolution that changes the system. bong uses kiwoo‚Äôs aspirations to show that whether an individual can climb the economic ladder does not matter because the cycle of class struggle will continue. kiwoo could become rich but the new tenants of his old family apartment will still get flooded out and the poor will continue to suffer while the ignorant rich continue to profit off the labor of the poor below them.

comment: Hi! I agree with what you're saying, although I think it might speak to a larger issue with theory and film analysis itself. When you apply a theory to a certain film, you're looking at it from a certain lens (in this case I looked at it from a socio-economic/cultural studies lens). I think it just requires multiple analyses and theories to observe the movie from different angles. Perhaps there's another theory that can explain why the Parks are victims. Maybe you could apply feminist film theory to explore Mrs. Park's character, or auteur theory to explore how Bong uses space/architecture to visualize his themes. But I don't think I could tackle all of the film's complex themes in a single video. I also agree that the relationship between the rich and poor is very complex and I don't think the Parks themselves are necessarily the villains of the movie, but actually the system they're living in ("we live in a society" lol). I also do think that the Parks' ability to physically remove themselves from the situation/house does speak volumes, even if they've experienced a traumatic situation. Thanks for the thoughtful comment!

comment:
Well. I grew up in South Korea during the 90's as a rich family but went to a public school for my parents believed that it is important for me to do that. After my birthday party as a kid, a lot of kids wanted to come over my house. They stole my toys and snacks. One kid who started to bully me a little was asked to leave and he smashed a window on the way out. Since we never moved, the "rich boy" stigma always followed and I was always bullied or cast out. When I went to collage, I thought it was a new start and never told anyone where I'm from all anything about my upbringing. But one day I let my guards down and invited a friend over to my place. After that the rich boy stigma began again. My friends always told me how I don't have to worry about student loans, that I don't really need to get a job, some even told me that me studying hard for exams was just for personal satisfactions while for others its about life and death. When I told them I never had friends growing up and was bullied all my life because of my family's wealth they just shrugged and said that's easy compared to being ordinary people's struggle.

My grandfather made an honest living. My dad also made an honest living. I hope I can make an honest living and continue the legacy. But I plan to "draw the line" from now on. I don't expect to be welcomed by the poor or the so called "normals" so I don't welcome them. I'm happy to live as a employer who pays handsomely and I'm happy that they see me just as that.

If you want to be happy as a normal dude, learn to be content or become rich. If you want to be happy as a rich, don't try to be down to earth or any of that bullshit because you will be hated. Pay handsomely and use that to draw your line.

comment:
parasite is a very well written movie It talks about power, greed and hope,it says that how humans are capitalist by nature, That a person only thinks about himself that when a poor family has power, they will not help other poor but will only think about themselves, There is a power hierarchy in the society and the one who has more power, he considers the one with less power as a filth. This film talk about privilege also that a higher class person gets everything but a lower class person has to work 10 times more to get that, Everything in this film was well balanced there is no villain in this film the real villain is the situation
Yes bong didn't give any reason for "all or nothing" but that's the whole point that's why it feels surprising,The murder of Mar Park by Mar kim was a very psychological act,The murder of Mar Park by Mar Kim is very surprising and to understand it, you need to understand the psychology of Mar Kim.
Kim never wanted to kill Park, it was the situation that led to this act,Jealousy and anger have already boiled over in Kim's mind against Park,And it's shown in a very subtle way,He used to respect the park a lot, but later he came to know that he just thinks of him as a worker who stinks alot This thing was deeply disturbing to Kim inside,A big truth was already revealed in front of Kim(secret bunker),And right after that he heard Mr. Park say about himself that he stinks, and later her whole house got washed away by the rain all trouble came upon him in one night Still, he has to go to work in the morning, where the Park family is about to enjoy a birthday party But still the park treats him like a worker wo stinks they are completely unaware of his problem,Even when geun se killed Kim's daughter, Park was only thinking about his son and he should logically think about his son first But Kim felt bad for this work of Park because of his hatred, when Park shrunk his nose to avoid the smell, then Kim felt worse,in that situation, his suppressed hatred and jealousy came out in the form of anger, which led to the murder of the park. Kim had no Big reason to kill Park and he never want to kill mr Park it just happened to him like a DREAM a BAD DREAM And he got punished for this because he did wrong he had to leave his family and stay in the bunker and later he also apologized to the park, but now nothing is going to happen with this apology, crime was already committed now he will have to atone for it ,this shows the jealousy and hatred of the lower class against the higher class, And the movie never justifies Kim's crime,Kim was not a psycho killer, he was a normal person, he committed this crime, which he regrets, but now nothing is going to happen by regretting,In the last, a conversation between a father and son is shown which is very emotional, a son will never consider his father a criminal He also knows that my father is not such a person, but nothing can happen now,In the end, the film ends on Hope, despite all this, ki woo never stops hoping,I don't know whether he will be able to get that house or not, but God bless him to buy such a house so that when it rains next time, he can enjoy it with his family like mr park does.
Both families were not parasite in this film the real parasite was human greed,hatred, jealousy and situation

comment:
This film is less a class critique than it is a subversive parody of the heist trope.

There is no consideration of the Parks at the end because, like a bank or art gallery, they exist to serve as a foil for the protaganists' whacky exploits.

There is certainly aesthetic contrast between the 'elevated' life and the 'subterranean' life, but this is to serve the parody.

As for it's creator's claim that the rich are parasites as well, I submit that he is trolling us -- that this is part of the parody. (After all, it depicts the Kim's as hiding like cockroaches under the furniture. And it portrays the anodyne Park family as ... having an evilly overactive olfactory sense? That's parody gold!)

Let the flaming commence! :)

comment:
I don't think the rich guy deserved what he got in the end. I think they are the victims here. They never treat them bad. Both the husband and wife give respect to the ones working for them. Only time he's not so respectful is when he talks about that smell and even then I didn't think it was enough to get him killed (plus leaving his kids fatherless and wife, widowed).
The poor family on the other hand conned them, stole two people's jobs when they could've certainly stopped at their son and daughter, used their living room when the family was away on a trip and used their food and alcohol. And to top it all of they're talking about having it all for themselves as if they worked for it (not to mention, how they treated that previous housekeeping lady and her husband). If they hadn't got greedy, none of those things would've happened. And when you consider that the rich guy worked from the bottom up (some Korean commenter said that), they're even more in the wrong.
I don't know if this was intended, but it seemed to me that the movie wanted us to feel a bit sympathetic for the poor family in the end. And because of that, I didn't like the ending. It was certainly cleverly made and very funny.

comment: I felt like the Kim's family met their Karma, even though it was depressing and awful.. First off, the two kids could have kept up the deception and atleast saved and try to better their circumstances. The sister, Ki-jung  had stood a really good chance because she was clever, talented and impressed the Park family. But what put me off was that they had the house keeper and driver dismissed out of pure selfishness and greed. They capitalized  too much off the situation. The second thing was that they outright refused to help the previous housekeeper even when she offered to pay them, yet they were in the same class as her. Plus they were the reason for her being out of a job. What would it cost to feed a guy once a week, when they themselves were deceiving the Park family. None of them took into account the mental health or desperation of the housekeeper and her husband. SMH.   And what I couldn't understand, how comes no one thought of their home which was in a basement during a storm. They were so caught up on trying to leave a rich lifestyle that they forgot their own home.

comment:
a student at my university wrote an essay last year on the amount of visible lines between characters in almost every shot - they‚Äôre separated by staircase railings, bookcases, walls in the background etc etc to show the division between classes. in addition there is an emphasis on height differences with characters moving up & down staircases, uphill and downhill, living in both basements, lying under the table etc. it‚Äôs an incredibly smart way that manages to properly Show these divisions and how poor people are invisible to the rich without explicitly saying so.

many people have tried to nitpick at this movie and say things like ‚Äùhow could the son have survived a blow to the head with a rock‚Äù or other minute critiques but im telling you, bong joon-ho thought of it all. the stone is a gift from his friend to represent academic success and serve as a good luck charm + source of aspiration, but when the basement is flooded it floats, showing how hollow the son‚Äôs hopes are whilst simultaneously solving what would otherwise be a possible plot hole. it‚Äôs clear that this movie was made with incredible care and effort. ive been a fan of bong joon-ho for several years now, so it is very satisfying to see him finally get the recognition he deserves. this IS a fantastically well made film and worth every last bit of the hype.


also it was kinda funny seeing celebrities praise this film without understanding it at alllll

comment: They scammed themselves into the jobs in the Park household but once into the job, they did the work, essentially and did the job well. Besides being overall, a social satire on the wealth/income divide in modern South Korea (and the world),  it shows also how the disadvantaged have so much trouble breaking into steady employment --- even jobs in households,  security guard jobs --- those jobs that conventionally are thought to be lower class jobs and supposedly easy to get.  The movie also shows that the poor aren't stupid, unqualified/unaccomplished or deserve to be poor --- they are just the vast majority who don't have the capital, the luck or other means to get further education, strike it in business, etc. because the post-capitalist world rewards the few and supresses the rest.  The real world is of course complex but the movie did a great job portraying a pretty realistic world while at the same time telling an engaging story that was funny, sarcastic, and tragic.  I agree,  virtually a flawless movie that was visually stunning.   I watched it late last year in a movie theatre --- remember those?

comment:
Bong: In this movie, the rich never look down at the poor. (ex driver, PM 2.5, under the table, the basement of my house, Morse code...)
And the poor don't dare look up. (They can't imagine deceive their owners to steal their homes or steal property. "Respect!", Just yelling and fighting among the same poor.)

There are no decisive villains in this movie. But from a small dispute, 'class murder' occurs.
Capitalism is said to be right, but what should we do about that 'gap'?
As mentioned above, The poor are becoming increasingly difficult to dream of gaining rank. And rich people are becoming less interested in others.

I'll just show you this time. Let's think together. What kind of society should we build?
(Of course, this is not a film that promotes socialism, it's a question of a better way in a capitalist society.)

comment:
No matter what wins any one single award, someone can always think of something that might be technically better and didn't get it. At the end of the day, something has to win and Parasite is a perfectly good movie with good writing, and a high degree of competency. For the year, I'm not sure I can think of a better Korean film, or one that isn't better in some ways but worse in others. I also don't think anything about it was over-hyped. It pretty much came out of nowhere and had very little mainstream hype.

The 2nd point about the smelly insult. You are watching the moment he makes a turn as a character. You have to think of that whole sequence as being together processed by him. The sniff is the straw that breaks the camel's back. He's clearly realizing things during the whole sequence. I had some issues with it too. I wish he had come to his realizations and made the turn a bit sooner. I thought while he waited in the bushes he was going to have put it all together and would have reacted "better" sooner. But the sequence doesn't fail. And if we look in real life, people end up often make that turning point late and at odd times. I've seen people put up with plenty of shit all day long, take in stride and be professional, but then go off "get triggered" because a tape dispenser is empty. Yes it might be nice if people took action at more opportune times, but they don't.

Two moments in a movie doesn't ruin it anyway. We can pick any movie apart until it looks like a train wreck. Frankly too, if you watch a lot of Korean or other foreign films, those two bits can't really bother you that much. Even just looking through the director and writers' filmographies....come on, you can't be that bothered by two explainable scenes otherwise...it feels like you just are looking for a reason to complain about Parasite.

comment:
Not a native English speaker so I am going to try my best.
First of all, let's give credit where credit is due: the movie is well shot, it builds some very artistic pictures at times, I find it funny, it has some cool metaphors, it's fast paced, accessible and enjoyable.
I also would like to assume that this is not an absurdist or surreal like film( stuff that you find in books written by Kafka, plays by Beckett or paintings by Dali, where common sense or logic are taken away for a specific purpose).
The action portrayed in the movie is supposed to be based on certain cause and effect situations, to make it realistic. Although, despite the general positive reviews that this movie has received, I'm afraid this is not the case. Parasite is anything but plausible, and here is why:

-Rich families may be superficial, but if the Parks in Parasite represent a symbol for rich families for an universal understanding, then everything is wrong. Rich people are not stupid, I find it odd that they do not have security cameras or some kind of guards to keep the house safe in their absence. It does not seem plausible that mrs and mr Park simply agree to hire this poor family without any research of their interests, or background.
I find it odd that they did not know, even though they bought such a big house, that they did not have a basement.

-It feels wired that they got rid of the old housekeeper, in such a manner, that they truly believe she had TBC. The scene where mr Kim spills ketchup on the used napkin is very reminiscent of some cheap Mexican soap opera. And then he just touches mrs Park hand :"Ah fuck it is just tuberculosis, relax"

-Its absurd of how the Kims simply do all that mess when the Parks are away.

-The aspect that the old housekeeper just comes back, saying that she forgot smth in the basement( a fucking human being), with all kinds of bruises, cutting out the camera, does not add up.

-The fact that the Kims where really skilled and street smart does not make any sense on how they did not find jobs before.

-After their already implausible escape, when they return to their flooded home, the Kims return for the young son birthday looking flawless, after they spent that night in odd conditions.

-In the birthday scene, after the parody-like events, in life and death situations, mr Park is annoyed by the smell?
really? when his son is dying he just wants his car keys, like no one else from the guests drives a car.

And these are just a few of the facts that the movie doesn't get right, it feels awkward.
Let alone the political message, where the old housekeeper mocks and imitates North Korean politics.
The are also so many cliches, like the moment when the Kims stumble and they are seen by the old housekeeper, in that particular moment.
And one more thing, I know that this movie is full of metaphors, but what kind of crime investigation does not properly search ALL the house, basement included.

The Kims demostrated to be extremelly smart and planning everything ahead, specially the kids. Then they make that stupid drunk party in the house risking loosing everything?. They let the old housekeeper just enters when they are all there with all the mess?. The main character has demostrated during the movie be very smart and focus in the detais, planning everything in advance, and then at the end, he decides in the middle of a party, with tons of people in the house, to go to the basement? And alone?. Then, like you said, the police is not going to find the basement after 3 killing in the house, they dont think, where this guy came from?. Specially having blood in the accesible basement.

Then, like you say, the cliches, like hidding under the bed, forcing the situation that everybody goes downstairs when everybody in under the table.

I find very silly the ending of the killing in the garden. After all the entire story that the writter has been able to construct, is he ending it like that, with a silly metaphor?.

I normally would have seen this movie and said, Ok, it is a good movie, and go on. But all this crazyness with a 99% in rotten tomatoes, and all the comment just saying that is the best movie ever and this like that makes me feel that I am the only one that has seen the movie.
I do not see where this movie really is the best ever.
- In cinematografy is fine, but it is far far far from being better that 1917, or Birdman, or Interstellar, or a ton of movies more.
- The actors are fine, but sometimes they did it quite bad, with those silly over reactions in their faces. People speaks about this acting like if Daniel Day-Lewis made them.
- The script is not that good. The original idea is good but the developement, specially in the half part is not well develope, not at least to make as good as people say. The writter abuse a lot of take the character way out of their personalities to make them do thing that produce the situation that the writer is forcing. Then those silly non-funny cliches like the scene of hidding under the table werent necessary at all.
-The ending is just a metaphore that the writter wanted to make even when it makes no sense and it is a silly ending, when he could have done something much better to develope the situation with the guy in the basement. You want to see a good ending, check Seven.

At the end, a good movie, but come on guys, it is not that good, it is really far from be a all times master piece. Maybe this overreaction is due to the fact that the last two years has been quite bad in real memorable movies. Or maybe people feel a little bit identified with some aspects of the movie. I do know.

I feel like when I was recommended to see "The mist", and when I check online the critics were throught the roof, and end up been one of the worst movies I have ever seen.

comment:
It‚Äôs about the class status and the inferiority difference between mr park and mr Kim. The resonance of his failure as provider for his family is always present with mr park as a comparison. The smell reference is more of viewing mr Kim as being below him on the class ladder, he also has to endure the embarrassment of his insults in front of his children.
Mr Kim is a very proud individual and especially in asian culture where a person‚Äôs status is defined by their monetary worth.
Given his mental state with his family‚Äôs current predicament of having their jobs a threat with the people tied down in the basement, his home being destroyed. Also the car scene where the mrs park is saying how great it was for the rain to fall to bring up this beautiful day for the garden party without knowing it destroyed his entire home.
Then his daughter bleeding to death his son unconscious bleeding from his head and even in an emergency situation mr park still has the bear of thought to hold his nose to retrieve the keys was his tipping point and he lost control. It was an act of impulse with which he instantly regrets.

comment:
What Parasite highlights is the appalling level of inequality in every society, which no one can turn away from.

Perhaps that‚Äôs why this film is already garnering widespread acclaim. It has already seized the Palme d‚ÄôOr along with multiple ¬≠international film awards.

There‚Äôs also speculation about whether it can be the first ever ¬≠non-English language film to win the Oscar for best picture.

The issues the movie shows are universal, and fitting of a world witnessing sweeping revolts and uprisings.

Revolutions and protests that removed decades-long dictators last year in Algeria and Sudan were built on the back of similar inequalities and resentments.

It is the poor and the have-nots who suffer the largest blow from ¬≠natural disasters as we can see from the floods in Indonesia.

The movie reminds us that it is not the rich and the powerful who pay for the consequences of global warming.

comment:
I think personally it delves into the characters‚Äô motives and personas very well. It especially outlines how in asian culture people‚Äôs social and wealth status is a measure of their value and success.
Scenes that stood out to me spoilers* are the belt of trust scene which is beautifully shot and edited along with the great score that accompanied it. When mr Kim has a final look back at his home before leaving in the flood was another stand out scene. The scene with mr Kim driving and the mother opens the window is also fantastic. I also loved the scene with mr Kim and mr park where they are dressed as American Indians, it brilliantly depicts the power of authority from wealth.

But movies are subjective to the people‚Äôs personal taste however for me it resonated. I think the film perfectly touches on the superiority complex and division from gaps in wealth and social status. The film also portrays how in today‚Äôs society we subconsciously view others inferior to us when they fall below us on the ladder and the constant struggle to elevate and project us up the class structure.

comment: Viewing the world of dichotomous the rich and the poor in neo-capitalist society from the perspective of the lower class. Life exists over the ground and under the ground. And semi-basement("Banjiha" in the movie) under the ground. And basement under the semi-basement. The traces of poverty that cannot be hidden remain unhidden. Life under the "Banjiha" coexists with the desire for the over-the-ground life and the fear of falling the under-the-ground. We can't share the happiness in our hands, so the gap between them is only widened. The film tells a dream that can't be fulfilled. The characters' performances are filled with all the scenes without any gaps, and they meet with humor like an awl even though they follow their hearts in unexpected ways. Even if you hide all hidden symbols and meanings, it is enough to enjoy the pleasure of the movie. It's such a lucky film I've met in my life.After watching a movie, I suddenly realize that I smell my smell and am surprised.

comment:
(NO SPOILERS)
Up to 75% into the movie...While I was intrigued from the start and up to that point I thought a few things "Oh, this is pretty clever and I don't think Ive seen such a story before"....AND...."While its interesting....I don't see why everyone is raving about it...I do...and Don't".
To that point is was a good movie....But once the Arch really went into full swing I found myself talking to my laptop screen....saying things like "NO DON'T" and "WTF??? WTF...JUST HAPPENED??"...AND...."OMFG"!!!

That last turn made me get why it had such an impact on a lot of people....Sure the class of people etc etc was packed into a good story....But I never thought to myself..."Usually lower income people etc are considered imbeciles in movies....If anything I roll my eyes a bit cause they are usually portrayed as victims...which also usually isnt the case IRL...IMO.

But this movie didn't treat them as imbeciles or victims....And also didn't treat the wealthy family as just evil people preying on others....I saw them as simply being raised a certain way etc and they had an outlook...but with no ill intent in mind.

Rich or poor...all had good and bad qualities...Which are subjective in a lot of ways anyway....it was nice to see that shown realistically for those characters while understanding no matter what side your on....This particular instance CANNOT be used as a generalization of either class....everyone is different.

THAT LAST 25% THOUGH....THAT CULMINATION WAS INDEED AN AMAZING TURN.

And the best line of the movie..."Oh, Mr. Park.... RESPECT"!!!!!!
That guy was hands down F'N Awesome haha.

Overall loved it.

comment:
:::SPOILERS::: What is it with you americans going all hurray for that film??? With all due respect (and love for Hollywood and independent movie makers in the US): have you missed european cinemas since the seventies?!I was shocked when I heard it got an Oscar , no: THE Oscar! I didn't know anything about 'Parasite' before watching it, so: perfect conditions, right? But I was not pleased. I liked the acting, tne camera work and art direction, but that's about it. I quite like the Korean movie scene too but this movie felt very european in a way, like one of those clever french comedies like 'Tanguy' for example. But: I have seen so many better scripts, more absurd plots and more cruel (and better developed) twists in the last decades (yes I'm old) that I was bored to hell in this one.
What is so fucking special, Bong Joon-ho did here? Admittedly, the basic idea is a neat one, but it goes nowhere. The characters acted like geniuses and improvised the bejesus out of them when the story needed it most - only to act like complete idiots: when the story needed it most. The only thing I did know when the film started (because I couldn't move my eyes fast enough away from the brief description) was that there is a plot twist. I hoped this would do the trick. For me it didn't. So there was a man hiding in the secret cellar. Wow. When they fell down the stairs so the real dramatic turning point that Joon-ho needed could occur I suffered a major second hand embarresment attack. That felt so insanly cheap I almost stopped watching. After that: why go dramatic after all?? Why have people dying????!!!! it made no sense. It was such an obvious and 'crafted' surprise - like uuuuh, NOW everybody will be shocked - that I felt nothing but: C'MOOOONs over and over again. Have the story escalate? Yeah sure, it desperately needed escalation at that point (and maybe before)! But why had it to be stabbing and thumping?! Don't get me wrong, I like my good amount of violence in a movie, but this felt so forced.
I don't hate that movie. It's worse. It bored me. And that's something I can never forgive ;)
Anyways, Chris, I just subbed, because I think you have a very engaging way of talking about movies, where both head AND heart are involved - like it should be in my opinion. Great stuff! Rock on!

comment:
A story there was. Thrilling scenes there were. Some pretty cinematography yes. Solid character build-up, hell no. Logical plot, no. Entertainment, not much. Consistency of characters, missing. Petty resentful ignorance towards the rich, yes. Narrow and shallow depiction of the poor, very much.

So not convincing. Every stretch of the movie i thought I started understanding the characters a bit more, but no, next stretch would make me scratch that understanding and try to rebuild again.. In the end, it made me fail to attach with any of the characters.

Without enough entertainment, what were the film makers trying to tell the audience? I completely don't get it.

Really doesn't match the hype. Wasted two hours of my life.

comment:
I analyzed the film. What you may have missed from the movie:

1. The most metaphorical scene is when they are splashing water to the crazy pissing guy. It summarizes the whole idea. CLUE: Water=Flood, Kims= Richer
Pissing guy= Poorer
And the dialog in that scene says a lot more about the film (rock foreshadowing, etc)

2. The arrangement of the poor family, everytime theyre eating is always the same, till second half comes. Order turned chaos.

3. Clothes are juxtaposed. Mrs Park's closet vs poor's second-hand relief clothes (scenes after flood).

4. Smell is a metaphor

comment:
I have seen Mother, Memories of Murder, Snow Piercer, and Host.

I was really looking forward to Parasite. To be frank, I was disappointed. Not that it is bad, but not good enough for me.
From the very start of the story, I found it not plausible, because we are introduced to a very poor family, and yet the son and daughter are exceptionally well informed about art, child psychology, education.
Maybe the South Korean low class schools are top notch?
Maybe it's a political statement: the poor are better educated than the rich, who are very gullible, ignorant, and unobservant.
I loved the scene where the poor mother swiftly pushes the maid down the stairs. But little else.
I have seen Mother and Memories of Murder twice. I doubt I will see Parasite again. I could not suspend my disbelief: If the son and daughter are so capable, why do they not have jobs?
And, the Basquiat-like painting by the rich kid. I just cannot believe a kid that age could produce something like that.
Plausibility comes first for me.

comment:
@Mayla Diosay Yes. I missed all of that, but it does not make it a better story. A film is basically a story. If the story starts out with anomalies, elements that do not compute, from that moment on, I lose interest.
All of the artistic elements that you cite fail to redeem this film for me.
I found the lawn party sequence, the attacks, strangely choreographed. The reaction of the guests and the hosts seemed oddly unresponsive to the violence taking place before their eyes.
I have read about the many artistic graces on display, but they do overcome my disbelief.

comment:
This movie is kind of a Parasite.

Here's a movie that should have been nominated and should have won the Oscar:

" The Laundromat "

It's a movie, which feels like a really likable informational video about insurance fraud and tricky money schemes... Lol... Antonio Banderas and Gary Oldman are just so much fun to watch!!! It's a delightful film! Based on a true story, as well, about the Panama Papers.

For me, this beats other movies nominated for movie awards. It's an artwork, turning a boring subject into pure fun, with a unique way to tell a story and make a point as well. The characters have their ups and downs, as well. It's a Steven Soderbergh project (I had thought he retired, so glad he didn't!) and his style lifts the story and turns it into an enjoyable ride that you want to be on.

Okay, I have nothing against "Parasite", but with all the English speaking great movies this year, why did this win so much at the Oscars? It had good directing, great acting, great score, interesting locations and good camera work -- but, I just didn't really believe the story that much. It seemed that the upper class folks were too naive, and the lower class folks were too lucky. Plus, what were the lower class family going to do once they were found out? After all, it was just a matter of time, right? The father of that family seemed to have a higher endurance, in my understanding of the character, but then he goes nuts because he finds out the upper class boss of his isn't fond of his 'smell'? Seriously? This just seems silly to me. I thought he was more humble, and with more grit than to let something like that bother him. Is it realistic that the upper class in South Korea don't check on anyone that they hire? Seems unrealistic to me. So, I really wanted the movie to succeed (for me) by having the characters strike a deal with each other, or reconcile and make an agreement of some kind that brings The 'human experience' to a higher level. But, instead, we got madness, chaos and murder. Wtf? I felt this was a complete cop-out. I'm guessing that this movie may have a more relevant sense to it, culturally, for those from South Korea or living there. Because it may be drawing from a reality, there, that could be worth evaluating more deeply. I thought this was an average movie, because of the story. 5 out of 10. Snowpiercer was more interesting, and better, from this Director.

comment:
I'm baffled at the amount of positive reviews this movie gets. I thought it was mediocre at best.

While I understood the plot of the movie, I didn't get why it was titled as "Parasite". I mean, who is the parasite? Society teaches us that the rich are not, because they (the father in this case) work for a living. The poor can't be, since they work, too.

So either no one is a parasite or, if we accept the premise of the movie, that someone is a parasite, we must agree that everyone is a parasite. The poor family is parasitizing the rich family. The rich father has a business which may be a legal form of scam, parasitizing its (poor) customers. His wife is parasitizing him. Their children are parasitizing them.

Extrapolating, there is no such thing as a parasite in nature, because in the end, every being is a "parasite" on the back of other being(s) in one way or another. Life feeds on life. It's just the way it is...

Therefore, because the concept of parasitism is such an ambiguous one, I think it was a bad choice for the title of this otherwise pathetic excuse of a movie.

parasite:
- an organism which lives on the back of another organism of a different species;
- a person who exploits others and gives nothing in return.

Now the poor family may be labeled as malevolent cheaters, but cheater doesn't necessarily mean parasite.

comment:
@Explicitghost Yeah... you didn't get my point.

Anyway, this movie is not a profound meditation on philosophical or social issues (though it pretends hardly to be that), so there is nothing "to read between the lines".

I've seen where the story would go after the first few scenes, so watching till the end was a grind more or less. Actually, to be honest, it exceeded my expectations in terms of how bad it was going to be. It is just a convoluted mess failing on so many levels, nothing more, though I understand why some people might mistake this for something that it is not. But a piece of crap is a piece of crap. Nothing more to say...

comment:
You answered how they are parasites in your later paragraphs buy ill recap. The poor family relies on exploiting the rich family to earn a living, doing so by scamming them and ruining the other house workers lives to replace them with their own family. The Rich family relies on the poor family to do the most basic of tasks to keep the home a livable place. They cant cook, do the dishes, or wash their own laundry. So in a way both families are parasites to each other. the twist of the movie serves as a grim reminder that it isn't just poor vs rich, but also poor vs poor as they battle for the welfare of the rich family. Being a parasite in the term you use isn't as simple as working or not working. Being caught up on simple issues like that hasn't allowed you to "read in between the lines" during your viewing of the movie.

You should give it a rewatch with that explanation in mind. Personally I think the film is great with amazing acting, writing, cinematography, and meaning. But it isn't perfect, it relies on deus ex machinas to push to the story along a little to much. But 100% a recommendation to anyone I know.

comment:
I'm Korean and one of the details most foreigners(and even Koreans) miss to mention is that those families were never like that poor/rich all the way through their life!

The rich family's dad is introduced in several details as he started from the bottom - and became an icon for it(The term Ja-Su-Seong-Ga is mentioned repeatedly+His company is an IT/Tech sort of company which makes it more believable). In the poor family's house, you can see several items/details where they were far more wealthier before(not super rich, but just better off in general) just that the poor family's father had a failed business that lead this family into this poverty. Thoses family members aren't incompetant at all. Dad has several great skillsets, mom was a national level athlete, sister is good at art, and the son is educated enough to teach the rich daughter.The sub-poor couple's husband even owned his own small business back in the day.

You act like you were born with the class, in reality, you're just stationed into a system. Capital hierarchy blinds you into believing the wealthy deserves of their own class while the poor believes the same, respectiong and admiring the upperclass. loads of casualty without any villans.

comment:
@Peeps and MooMoo I get the point you initially followed and yes the ending was intended to make you feel that way. It was never about anybody 'deserving' of anything. The intention of the director(as he famously admitted all the time)was this.

Most of the time bad things only happened to both the poors. They were conned, they lost their jobs, they lost their house, they lost their dignity, they lost the sense of existing as a human being and reduced down to their occupation and function. they were invisible to the rich. whenever they tried to connect with the rich(like asking if they loved there SO and asking for a handshake) the rich appeared as if they were offended even, as if they were crossing a line or something.

There is no justification for the killing. Heck even the poor dad felt guilty of his actions. the director wanted to point out that as long as this inhumane class hierarchy of welth exists, very very bad things will definately happen to anyone, even the rich. it's not a matter of right or wrong, or who deserves what, it will happen.

even tho they try so hard, the rich family is highly disfunctional without the poors labor. however they draw an imaginary line between them and the poor. you can hate the poor hold them accountable for their action. but no matter what, once in a while an end of a knife blade will definately be headed towards you if this class system exists. the director wanted the ones who justify and lives(wins) upon this system to acknowledge that it horrible things may happen to them.

Stick man said the poor family were pretty smart people, and I agree. So couldn‚Äôt they find a better way to get by without ruining the lives of others? comment: I just saw the movie and I agree that it's fantastic and one of the best of the year, but that's a really long list for 2019. I just thought the massive plotholes were the only things keeping it from being a true masterpiece. Why didn't he just say "hey my sister would be good for this?" why did he have to pretend he didn't know her? They didn't seem to have already formulated the entire plot of bringing them all in, and I don't recall them ever mentioning why he didn't want them to know they were related. Also the buttons that controlled the lights were pretty unbelievable. Like why would that have been built that way? That was a huge MacGuffin that I found distracting when it came up. Also nothing ever came of the young boy decoding the message, so that seemed pointless. But despite all of that it was a great film and the acting and cinematography were near perfect. It's a must-see for sure.

comment:
i didn't feel this movie was authentic. it's more like a movie was made to fit a particular social narrative, which actually hampers the authenticity of the story and the story feels forced. the poor family is extremely smart and skilled and it's unclear how they could be so poor with all that. .people who are smart and have little regard for ethics usually thrive in a market economy even if they start with less resources.




certain situations and scenes seems highly unlikely (father not getting caught or the bunker not being found after such a horrific crime, the father surviving in the basement for years without any external help, The family's extremely reckless behavior when the rich family goes out for just one night and equally reckless and stupid actions that makes them get caught to the previous house keeper, the son fully recovering - let alone surviving - two full blows to the head with a very heavy rock) and i feel these highly improbable situations are due to the film-maker trying to push the story to fit a particular social narrative. these are common in foreign movies that are made to a western market. i highly doubt the movie was equally well accepted by the S. Korean domestic audience.




the social critique too is ambiguous (if that was done purposely, it would be great, but i highly doubt it). for instance, i thought the person living in the bunker represented those who live from welfare. well is that a criticism of the welfare system? if it is, then maybe there's a point. but trying to justify the jealousy and anger of the poor family doesn't sit well. ultimately, a son saw his father getting killed in front of him and a wife lost her husband for the only reason that they were rich and successful and somehow that doesn't count? perhaps that guy worked his ass off to reach that position. resources don't just appear out of thin air. it's the same socialist destructive and negative mindset. it looks like the poor family is just in that situation cos they never took responsibility for their lives and in some situations it's even suggested. and it's actually the poor family that doesn't give a shit about the fellow man and undercut other poor people (like the former drive and the land lady, the boy even steals his friend's gf who helped him land a job). somehow the rich guys are assholes bcos the wife is naive and the husband doesn't like the driver poking on his private life and doesn't' like how he smells? common. all this is mixed up with a forced socialist message maybe to fit a western liberal audience so ultimately the social critique too loses its focus.




All in all, i think the film is overrated cos it tried to fit a particular social narrative and wasn't true to the story. it's a very common issue with modern movies. it's why even though these films are called 'masterpieces' they never reach the levels of classics like 'seven samarui' or '12 angry men' (or even 'Joker'). cos rather than staying too to the story and characters, movies like this try to fit a contemporary political ideology, which compromises the integrity story and character development.


i liked the movie was switching genres throughout . it is something that can become a new trend.

The main character, base in his personallity, would have never go down to the basement in the middle of a party, because during the movie the guy demostrate to be a masive planner, thinking out of everything, and then, he is doing that?. You cannot see that in City of God, Seven, American Beauty, Good Will Hunting, etc. That is the biggest criticism that I have with the script, that forces situations abandoning the "how that character would act in that situation". comment:
I enjoy your movie reviews, and sometimes I decide to watch movies because of you. You made me watch this movie, and thank you for that. After watching this movie at the theater, I was not able to stop thinking the movie that day. I am not sure whether you gonna post a Parasite extended spoiler review or not, but I want to share how I felt about the movie. I am originally from South Korea, so I got used to both US and Korean cultures. My understanding of the movie could be different from you. There are so many things to talk, but I believe water, a stone (scholar's rock), and ghosts are important symbols.
1) Water: Have you taken a shower with cold water? You can try just 1 minute very cold shower, not warm& hot water. It initiates your fight or flight response and makes you discomfort. The drunk guy from the beginning of the movie got cold water to wake up. I think water reveals who they are here, and water naturally flows down because of gravity inevitably. The Kim's family's day-dream (to be rich) at the Park's house has ended with rain, and they confront a brutal reality. The Park's family reveal their disgust about the poor when raining
2) A stone (scholar's rock): I think the stone means superficial wealth or luxuries like a Gucci bag. There's no real use of the stone here, it is an object to show off. $3000 Gucci bag is useful or practical for a person who makes $3000 per month? probably not. In our daily life, media constantly tell you that you have to buy those items to look like a rich person. The media owned by rich people, tell you that the poor people are worthless, and the rich people should be respected. In the movie, the stone shows up when flooding, and it is like "id" (your primitive desire) emerges from "superego" (conscience, reality=water). The son in the movie can't hide his desire to be rich. His deep inside clings to the stone, thinks the poor is worthless even though he is one of the poor.
3) Ghosts (morse code): Funny that this reminds of Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon (one of the richest people in the world), have you heard that Amazon workers can't even go to bathroom often? Ms. Park says that you will be rich if you live in the house with ghosts (hard working class, the poor). The poor are like ghosts here. The rich don't want to believe the poor exist or don't want to see them, but the rich need the poor to support their luxury life style. The guy in the basement blindly respects Mr. Park even though Mr. Park doesn't even know the guy exists.


Anyway, this is just what I think after watching the movie. Again, thanks for your movie reviews.

comment: A picture is worth a thousand words: blood splattered on cake. ‚ÄúLet them eat cake‚Äù was Marie Antoinette‚Äôs retort to the starving masses. The blood of common workers is on the cake - the bread of the aristocracy. Sugar plantations‚Äô slaves toil to produce the sweetness of pampered lives. The frontal head shot of indigenous features in full native head dress shows in the most subtle way how the rich have obtained advantage: the nonchalance of a violent genocide in a land grab. The seeming ease with which some come into wealth is depicted by just walking up, by avarice, or marrying up. At first glance, clothes and demeanor differentiates the rich from the poor. This determines who gets ‚ÄúRespect!‚Äù The poor are treated like vermin to be exterminated. Even the toilet is elevated above where the poor lives. Passerby routinely "piss on them.‚Äù The smell of poverty remains even as they pass for fitting in.

Just saw it and really liked it, however I found a plothole towards the end, so SPOILERS?

When Kevin was hit over the head with his own rock by the crazy basement guy he's lying right by the steps to the underground secret bunker area and the door is open. We also know the door stays open because his father goes through it afterwards on his escape after killing the rich dad and uses the handle to close it. So the plothole is: Kevin lies there unconcious, almost dead, and he is found by the daugther of the rich and family and she carries him upstairs where chaos ensues and runs away with Kevin on her back. We see this too. But she never noticed the open door to the hidden basement area that was in her house all along and that she didn't know about and wondered wtf it was? I know she wouldn't think about it in the moment because of panic, but afterwards she would have told the police about it if she did notice. And we know that she never told the police because the dad of the poor family hid down there and they were never able to find him. Meaning that the police at the end still doesn't know about the hidden bunker area. Thoughts?

I think perhaps (western) people who are watching this movie who don't know anything about Korean culture, watch a lot of Korean dramas or shows be disadvantaged at getting references will miss is that the show is unmistakably Korean through and through. comment:
Some things I noticed/learned about the move. Spoiler alert






First:
Someone commented how unrealistic that the rich family never noticed the sliding door (with metal track on floor visible) that reveals the path down.


And the rich couple don't notice the people hiding under the table.


The rich couple don't notice things under them, because they don't look down. Consciously and unconsciously, they don't look down. They don't want to see/know/interact with what's under them, because it makes them uncomfortable, vulnerable, etc. That's a line the rich couple don't want to cross down.


But the poor are always looking up. The poor family looking out the widow from the semibasement home. Looking up the steep path/stairs going up as they head to the rich family's home.



Second:
Also, the large window in the rich family's living room has the ratio of 21:9. When the rich look out from the living room, what they want to see OR inevitably see is entertainment. Like seen through a wide aspect screen.




So many layers and layers of meanings in all the scenes.

Spoilers ahead



1) GEUN-SAE sends an S.O.S. message in morse code. DA-SONG sees it from his tent in the garden and writes it down... but that never comes into play. What was the point?
2) KI-TAEK stabs MR. PARK because he covered his nose. Before, KI-TAEK noticed the PARKS reacting that way to him. Like there was a "poor people" smell. They're both fathers who have to help their children, yet MR. PARK still thinks something as shallow as the smell is something to be concerned about during an emergency. Also, early on, DA-SONG was sniffing the KIMS and said "They have the same smell." The KIMS took him as him noticing that they eat the same food or that they use the same detergent. comment:
I didn't know what to expect from this movie. The trailer told me just enough to draw interest without giving too much (if anything) away. I couldn't even get a read on what genre or genres it might fall into.

With almost every line, I was more intrigued at the plot, invested in the cast, engrossed in the world, and impacted by the atmosphere. The pacing felt perfect from scene to scene, minute to minute.

Not one character felt unnecessary, and I never felt like I was being hand-held through anything such as with exposition. As the story & tone shifted, my enjoyment went from laughing to being disturbed.

My first thought was "WTF? Is this actually a horror/thriller? A dark satire? A black comedy? What's going on here?" I can't explain it without spoilers, but compare it to Doki Doki Literature Club's twist.

My reaction was very similar (albeit, more sudden) the first time I went through that game. Anybody who's played knows exactly what I'm talking about and remembers how THAT scene affected them.

Everything takes a tonal 180 and only escalates from there. Parasite's twist wasn't as immediate or in-your-face, but definitely every bit as surprising in the best way. It's an absolute masterpiece imo.

comment:
The meaning of parasite(Both the rich and the poor are parasites!!)
- There are two meanings
1) infiltrate : the poor(Gitak's family and the basement family) infiltrate their money and place. And also the rich(Park's family) also infiltrate the poor and suck up their labors.
2) aversion(abhorrence): We generally abhor the parasite. If the rich and the poor don't respect each other, there are possibility for them to abhor each other because of various reasons. The limitation of Capitalism is that the gap between the rich and the poor is widening. The poor's deprivation and the rich's ignorance toward the poor can come into "conflict".
It means that the rich regard the poor as parasites and vice versa.
These days, One's effort can not lessen the gap between the rich and the poor. But it is possible the rich to harmonize with the poor and vice versa.
If the rich only think that there is a invisible line, the conflict can not be solved.
is it possible the rich and the poor become real friends at each other? How about trying to understand each other, and how about giving consideration and respect toward each other?
Then our world - The world of capitalism - can coexist between the two, and we should try not to make a world where the rich and the poor abhor each other.
In other words, Don't regard each other as a Parasite!! It only accelerates the demerit of Capitalism.


This is why the title of this film is parasite.

comment:
I've known NOTHING about this, other than "It's Horror" and "It's Asian", and that alone, is good enough for one of my friends, who is REALLY into this stuff, and says that, if you only watch 80's slasher flicks, you're not ready for something like, say, Martyrs (sp?). I've heard of Martyrs, from this friend, and I get that Japanese horror flicks are not for the casual western viewer, who only knows Freddy, Jason, Pennywise, the Xenomorph, the Terminator, the Predator, etc. It's a big leap from the 80's action/horror cliches, to the whole world of Japanese horror, especially the less commercial stuff. And I totally get the fear of jumping from "Generic 80's blockbuster horror" to "Japanese stuff you definitely haven't heard of before, trust me, it's sick" (and that Joss Whedon had some stuff from The Ring and some of that Eastern Horror featured in Cabin In The Woods, as just a taste of what "Eastern Horror" has in store". I haven't really seen anything in that Eastern Horror section. But. If I were to find myself wanting more, I think something like Parasite, from what I have heard, it does sound like a good "gateway drug" into this area in horror movies.


And reviewers, critics, and the like, who I already subscribe to, saying that this is GOOD, is definitely something to take seriously. I have seen that, from just a "brief glance", critics saying "Parasite is a good, Asian horror movie" around the board, is enough to get my attention.


Maybe I'll see it, when I think I'm brave enough. Horror movies aren't my first choice. I'm more "Epic, badass, sci-fi/fantasy" or "real, poignant drama" as a viewer, than I am a "I wanna get my kicks on horror flicks" kind of viewer. I've never really loved horror movies. Some are awful, some are too much to deal with, I could really use a guide, etc etc. But I do hear that Parasite is good, from multiple voices around me (wow, that could be interpreted wrong!) so I may check this out. Soon. If the thing-that-is-the-monster doesn't get me first, that is.

comment: I usually get skeptical when a movie wins the Palme d'Our. Sometimes there's really good movies that win the award and sometimes there are movies that are... well, at least not for me. But I recently watched Parasite and I think it's one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. This might be one of my all-time favorite foreign movies. I think this is the kind of movie that critics and regular moviegoers can love because it's not too artsy and ambiguous for the regular moviegoer and it's not too "mainstream" for critics and deals with themes that a lot of people can identify with. Even though Endgame might be my favorite from this year, this is a very close second. I seriously think this is one of the best movies I've seen in the past at least five years.

comment: Saw this film days ago and I echo every sentiment. I fucking loved everything about it. I tend to understand how some people might find even excellent films kinda boring because there's some truth to it where even high art films don't always aim to entertain the average viewer because it requires more investment and it prioritizes delivering a message or a unique experience more than it does to just entertain. But I honestly cannot imagine anyone finding this boring even if it is up there in excellence because it's made in a way where it's able to cater even to the most casual of tastes given its really entertaining nature and inviting cinematography. The dialogue doesn't go out of its way to be vague and complicated. Everything they say in here is exactly what a regular person would say but used in ways that serve the scenes extremely well. Man, I could talk about this film all day but this review nails the best parts of it well. Everyone must watch this film.

comment:
docsamson198 I agree. I didn‚Äôt know what to expect as I didn‚Äôt see any trailers or read reviews. I just kept seeing so much praised heaped on it so I had some free time and went to the cinema down the street. I was totally expecting a serious drama about a lower class family and their struggles. I was not expecting such a lighthearted, smart, and funny film. The pacing of the film zips by for the first half. There‚Äôs so much to love about how the story plays out that when the reveal happens that introduces the next story arc, I was completely surprised by it.

It still managed to be funny, but with darker undertones, and it gradually became a tragedy only to shift into another stylistic tone. And it executed it so well without it seeming forced or gimmicky. I think this merging of tones is a welcomed surprise for western audiences who may normally think of foreign films as high brow, intellectually stimulating but otherwise boring movies. This felt modern, quick, smart, clever, and it pulls off something very tricky‚Äînot taking itself so seriously but also not being frivolous and empty. I think it truly rewards the viewer and shows how filmmakers can tell engaging, sharp stories in new ways that still feel somewhat grounded in the familiar. Very enjoyable film. One I‚Äôd like to see again.

comment: I haven't seen Lighthouse yet, so I cannot comment on that. This year, I was waiting for parasite to be released as soon as I heard that Bong Joon Ho was directing it. I had humongous expectation. I watched movies like Us, Joker, endgame, Midsomer.., but something was missing in all these movies, even though they all are really good movies. But, Parasite completed my cinema viewing experience this year. On the first viewing, without having any knowledge about the movie, I was blown away. Like if you have big expectation, even though the movie is good, it can bring down your experience with the movie. But its not that case here.  It is undoubtedly the best movie this year. On the second viewing, I can safely say that this is a masterpiece. The story, direction, acting, cinematography, everything is great. Every dialogue, every scene, every object in the movie is meaningful in its own way. I highly recommend people to watch this movie.

comment: Hmmm. I'm slightly torn. I really enjoyed the film, but that mostly hinged on how the ending tied everything together. Everything that preceded it was an extremely well made suspenseful black comedy, but it felt slightly Coen Bros or Hitchcock lite at times. But that ending, without spoiling the film, was incredibly heartwarming when you consider everything that preceded it. It also had a good message that didn't feel cheap. I felt it had a better ending than Snowpiercer, and that's why it's the better film to me. All of his films are great, though. Not one misstep in the bunch (I haven't seen Barking Dogs yet).

comment: I had a hard time getting super invested in this film because I didn't like any of the characters. I felt like they were all kind of shitty people doing heartless things and I didn't care what happened to any of them. So I found myself feeling something I almost ever feel during movies: boredom. Also I felt this movie lived between reality and fantasy in a way where it didn't really take advantage of either the emotion of relatability or the visceral experience of the fantastic. This movie moved past believability for me but didn't ever seen to take advantage of the strange reality it created. I will agree it was immaculately crafted, but I felt it was a bit sterile and forgettable. My grade: B

‚ÄúMovies are back!‚Äù 2 A+ within a week?!

2017 was it for me. Logan. Baby Driver. Blade Runner 2049. Guardians of the Galaxy 2. Thor Ragnarok. Kong Skull Island. It. Alien Covenant. Wind River. Hostiles. Spider-Man Homecoming. Kingsman 2. War for the Planet of the Apes. Dunkirk. Wonder Woman. Get Out. John Wick 2. Three Billboards. King Arthur. Shot Caller. American Made. Logan Lucky. A Monster Calls. Lost City of Z. Mother. Brawl in Cell Block 99.

So many more, a lot of other great indie films and lower profile ones too, those are just the big ones that come to mind. A year of great variety!
